pr_title: Fix missing trajectory segment bug, removed deprecated code
pr_contents: This has the fix created by
as discussed in
where he says:

I looked at the joint_trajectory_controller code and I found that the start time of the first trajectory segment is calculated using the previous period. This might cause that the start time of the first trajectory is later than the next sample time when the previous period is longer(even 1us) than the current period because of the jitter. And this leads to the above error.
I ran his fix overnight with continuous trajectory interruption and the error did not occur again.
I've also removed a code block that was intended to be removed in indigo, and I added a section for optionally measuring message latency in actionlib using compiler flags.
Thank you for your quick work.
I'm not sure that the threshold is reasonably small or it should be smaller. I chose period because I didn't want to include any extra magic parameter.
I'm not sure either, I just know it works for me :)
Hopefully
can weight in
we are so slow here... :)
Will you have some time to separate this PR into 2 and send it against kinetic-devel?
I would like to merge the deprecation one and we can discuss about the segment one.
I'm afraid I do not currently have any projects requiring ros_control and I am focusing my energy on MoveIt and my looming thesis defense. Feel free to take over these changes.
pr_quotes: I looked at the joint_trajectory_controller code and I found that the start time of the first trajectory segment is calculated using the previous period. This might cause that the start time of the first trajectory is later than the next sample time when the previous period is longer(even 1us) than the current period because of the jitter. And this leads to the above error.

pr_title: Adding battery voltage information to ROS msg
pr_contents: Recovering feature from v3.2.
I can't find any reason why this feature has been removed in
With this change battery voltage information (V) is provided in topic "/dji_sdk/battery_state". Tested with not DJI original batteries + A3 autopilot.

pr_title: Added recover and stop in RobotHW
pr_contents: Proposal for extension of RobotHW with recover and stop functions for easier hardware management. See code comments for explanation of this functions. Hope this can be also useful for many other robots, since we are using it with Schunk modules/robots and rob@work mobile robot.
I'm in favour of this— particularly when using combined_robot_hw, it would be nice to have a way to notify all RobotHW plugins to stop or start up again based on some external system state.
Should there be something added to ControllerManager to actually call the stop function on shutdown, since the comment hints that that will occur?
Could you please add a test that could double as a reference implementation for our documentation as well please?
Also, if the rob@work drivers are public that'd be a nice addition :)
I am not sure about this..
In which case should these functions get called and by which part of the chain?
I can see
' point with combined_robot_hw, but this PR does not address this fully.
IMHO we need interfaces in the other direction, to notify that some joints are not active anymore.
Also, if the rob@work drivers are public that'd be a nice addition :)
rob@work is the industrial version of Care-O-bot, almost all  of the (original) drivers are public.
: Regarding ControllerManager we have our own generic implementation of ControllerManager since I was annoyed to write for every hardware
controller manager code.
For the example of the generic controller manager see under.
: Would something like this be suitable as test?

: one of the main reasons to implement this is actually better support for hardware drivers provided by your department (e.g. rob@work, schunk_modular_robotics). Without this on any error, or after Emergency-Stop you can only restart the component completely...
Regarding ControllerManager we have our own generic implementation of ControllerManager since I was annoyed to write for every hardware the same controller manager code.
Your code uses the standard ControllerManager..
I have just noticed that RobotHW got
and
functions
IMHO these should have been added to a derived, but abstract
class.
Now we can combine any RobotHW, but cannot run it, because not all classes actually implement these functions.
Originally,
was meant to provide state/command access to controllers, but not to grant full, exclusive control over the hardware.

one of the main reasons to implement this is actually better support for hardware drivers provided by your department (e.g. rob@work, schunk_modular_robotics). Without this on any error, or after Emergency-Stop you can only restart the component completely...
Our department switched to
, which already implements this (init, halt, recover, shutdown services) ;)
That's one of the reasons we proposed
in the first place..
Your code uses the standard ControllerManager..

Yes. What I meant is that is reused on multiple hardware. Currently for most of the RobotHW implementation there is also CM implementation to start the node (it is not wrong, but not efficient for managing 5+ robots)
Originally, RobotHW was meant to provide state/command access to controllers, but not to grant full, exclusive control over the hardware.
OK, but how should be than responsible for hardware initialization and stopping? In current implementation for initialization is CM but not for stopping. IMHO we can put it in RobotHW interface...
Our department switched to ros_canopen, which already implements this (init, halt, recover, shutdown services) ;)
That's one of the reasons we proposed std_srvs/Trigger in the first place..
I know. I am also using your repositories  on daily basis :) Actually this was also inspired with your CM implementation in
. the problem came when we added other Schunk hardware (not canopen capable) in ros_control (pw70 and SDH). I can also share my code, but currently depends on our internal ros_control extension :)
This would be really useful - I would strongly vote for this to be merged! I would also propose to add this functionality to the CombinedRobotHW class
I am very interested in having such methods in the hardware interface for a simple robot (
) or a composed one (
, which is lacking in this pull request).

In our case, we want to implement a wireless soft emergency stop for our battery-operated robots. This seems to be the best place to stop and restart the robots. On the restart, we would then have the controller manager's
method be called with the
option enabled.
We had considered the option of switching controllers, but this seems to be an other possible point of failure in the system, which we would like to avoid.
Hi all,
we updated our branch to be compatible with combined_robot_hw. Is this no OK?
This applies here as well:
pr_quotes: Also, if the rob@work drivers are public that'd be a nice addition :)
Regarding ControllerManager we have our own generic implementation of ControllerManager since I was annoyed to write for every hardware the same controller manager code.

one of the main reasons to implement this is actually better support for hardware drivers provided by your department (e.g. rob@work, schunk_modular_robotics). Without this on any error, or after Emergency-Stop you can only restart the component completely...
Your code uses the standard ControllerManager..
Originally, RobotHW was meant to provide state/command access to controllers, but not to grant full, exclusive control over the hardware.
Our department switched to ros_canopen, which already implements this (init, halt, recover, shutdown services) ;)
That's one of the reasons we proposed std_srvs/Trigger in the first place..

$ more /opt/jsk/bin/rtcd.sh
#!/bin/sh

export JSK_DIR=/opt/jsk
export LOG_DIR=/opt/jsk/var/log
export PATH=$JSK_DIR/bin:$PATH
export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=/opt/nextage-open/lib:/opt/jsk/lib:$LD_LIBRARY_PATH ## use libhrpIo.so in /opt/nextage-open/lib
#export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=$JSK_DIR/share/nextage-open/lib:$JSK_DIR/lib:$LD_LIBRARY_PATH ## use libhrpIo.so in /opt/jsk/share/nextage-open
export RTCD_KILLNAME=rtcd

OS=`uname`
if [ "$OS" = "Linux" ]; then
  KILLALL="/usr/bin/killall -q"
elif [ "$OS" = "QNX" ]; then
  # On QNX many libraries requreid for hiro-nxo are installed via pkgsrc, which goes into /usr/pkg.
  export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=/usr/pkg/lib:$LD_LIBRARY_PATH
  KILLALL=/bin/slay
fi

#
# loop for rtcd
#
mkdir -p $LOG_DIR
$KILLALL -9 $RTCD_KILLNAME

while :; do
    /opt/nextage-open/bin/unlock_iob

    if [ -f $LOG_DIR/rtcd.log ]; then
        rm $LOG_DIR/rtcd.log
    fi

    DATESTRING=`date +%Y%m%d%H%M%S`
    ln -s $LOG_DIR/rtcd-$DATESTRING.log $LOG_DIR/rtcd.log
    rtcd -f /opt/jsk/etc/HIRONX/hrprtc/rtcdRobotMode.conf > $LOG_DIR/rtcd-$DATESTRING.log 2>&1

    /usr/bin/env sleep 1
    $KILLALL -9 $RTCD_KILLNAME
    /usr/bin/env sleep 1
    $KILLALL -9 $RTCD_KILLNAME
done

hrpsys backward compatibility

pr_title: [hrpsys_ros_bridge] hrpsys_dashboard.py add tool tip for servo on/off
pr_contents: does anyone use power on/off?
is it possible to add your start/stop impedance button at here?
インピーダンスを入れるのに，limbの先端のjoint名が必要で，
それがロボットごとに違うので諦めるということが半年くらい前にありましたが，
最近のhrpsys-baseのインピーダンスに更新があって
今ならlimb名だけでインピーダンスをstart/stopできるようになっていたりしますでしょうか？
さん
を見ると力センサ名だけが必要になったようです．
HRP2の手先センサ名は lhsensor, rhsensor となっていて，
色んなロボットでこれが同じであればすんなりできそうです．
違う場合はどうするのがいいでしょう．
（STAROはlasensor, rasensorみたいになっていて，HRP2とは違った気がしています．）
遅くなりました。
引数は今いくつか整理しつつあって、わりと最後の悩みポイントが
とするか
とするか、でした。
ImpedanceControllerの内部では力センサと1対1にデータポートがついて、ImpedanceParamも使える状況になってます。
基本的には後者の"rarm"などがロボットの差異もなくて良いと思いましたが、
後者だと同じrarmないに複数センサがある場合に使い分けられないとおもい、どうしようかと思いました。
ただ、やはり同じrarmに複数センサがある状況はなしと考えて良いきがしてきたので、
にしようと思います。
にも関係しますが、もし複数のhrpsys-baseのバージョンで動かすのであれば
のようなstartImpedance的な関数をhrpsys_config.pyに追加して、
としておいて、dashboardからはstartImpedanceとだけ呼べばどちらも動くように思います。
pr_quotes: さん
pr_details_more: 基本はhrpsys-base最新のインターフェースに揃えておく
もし古いバージョンを使うのであればhiornx.pyなど個別のロボット.pyで対応する

pr_title: Add validity checks for range and defaults
pr_contents: a) the range for a parameter is impossible to meet
b) the default is out of range
Having those errors in a cfg file can be tedious work to find/debug
ping
Any chance to fix the two failing builds from my side? IMHO they are in no way related to my changes but were existing before (
) but I may be wrong here
Sorry for the long delay on this. I'll try to get around reviewing pending PRs in the next few days.
the failing tests seem to be unrelated to this PR, it can be reproduced on master and is tracked at
great to hear. However the impact of this pr might be quite substantial and require work on "unknown buggy" packages/config files
great to hear. However the impact of this pr might be quite substantial and require work on "unknown buggy" packages/config files
Correct, we will need to build every known ROS package using

to see how many do not comply. If this proves to require many changes in downstream packages we will need to hold off that change for the next ROS release (ROS Noetic) and make sure to file PR on every package that requires a change
retest this please
I finally found the hours needed to test this on Kinetic (tested all packages depending directly on dynamic reconfigure).

There are several packages failing, some are warranted failures but for some the check seems a bit too restrictive. For example the comparison is made regardless of the parameter type, for string for example it may not make sense to do a comparison (arguably it may not make much sense to give a range to a string parameter in the first place..).

Some packages seem to set out of range values purposefully, I guess it's to reflect the "uninitialized" state. Though to confirm I guess we should reach out to the maintainers of these packages to see if it's a valid assumption.
List of packages failing with this change (10 out of 159):
RE:

For example the comparison is made regardless of the parameter type, for string for example it may not make sense to do a comparison (arguably it may not make much sense to give a range to a string parameter in the first place..).
This was actually a broken chekc in dynamic reconfigure and should have failed regardless of this PR (addressed in

pr_contents: Examples and interface for motion planning in C++ code using MoveIt.
May need to change
and
parameters to
in ompl_planning.yaml.
The coding follows kinetic version of MoveIt documents not the 2013 one.

Currently the interface does not allow setting goal_constraints with position and orientations (I have never gotten solutions within 10 minutes with this pattern). The interface calculates inverse kinematics and then calculates collision avoided paths between start joints and calculated goal joints (if the goal joints have collision, basically the planning will fail).

I have checked that the planning works with constraints (e.g. not changing the pose of the end effector). However, the planning is slow, it takes between 10 to 60 seconds to get a solution with constraints. The collision avoidance may give weird motion.
merge if seems okay. If not, please give reasons. Also please check if the samples run.
The sample shows an example of returning a motion trajectory that avoids hitting a container (the robot will hit the container if angles are sent directly without the motion plan)
We used move_group interface for using planning interface.
I think move_group is useful for handling collision objects.
You can launch aero_moveit_config/launch/real_robot.launch for testing move_group interface with rviz.
can you provide examples (similar to the ones pushed) in aero_samples using the move_group interface?

by the way, it seems there are two different types of interfaces. The move_group one communicates over a node, the one used in the pull request runs within C++ code. We could have both ways unless you insist there should only be one way of running codes to avoid confusion.
Anyway, I am wondering whether solving the pose goal will work with the node version.
updated comment. see on github
added some code related to
note, if anyone has trouble running code in kinetic with "RRTstar", this could be changed to "RRTConnect" (although RRTstar gives a better optimized trajectory).
This sample runs for both indigo and kinetic. I've checked that the samples also work with gazebo.
Although there is already the moveit interface, the interface in this pull request allows more native control and access to the moveit functions.
There should be no problem with having such an interface, it's only an option and both ways of using moveit is official.
In other words, I'd like to have this merged. Thanks.
I strongly recommend to use move_group.
If we start to build raw moveit interface, we will build another move_group in future.
Then at least I would recommend having the following functions for aero:
And to make sure that
And I would like the following samples:
Until these are supported I cannot move on to using the move_group interface.

Please check and let me know if this is true. eef::grasp is a virtual link and does not have actual shape. I was not able to get a solution applying end effector pose for 20 minutes. The planner returns a solution within a second with eef::hand.
But it is not so important if you can solve plan successfully.

If you set a rough planning, the calculation becomes faster but the actual plan could have collision. Depending on the problem (or even machine power), it might be better to do a rough plan multiple times and find one solution without collision rather than waiting for one successful plan that takes time.
So I disagree with your comment.

Please check and let me know if this is true. eef::grasp is a virtual link and does not have actual shape. I was not able to get a solution applying end effector pose for 20 minutes. The planner returns a solution within a second with eef::hand.

to values larger than 0.005. However, this will return a rough plan that sometimes collide with the environment. This type of plan requires an additional check on the planned trajectory.

pr_title: Don't insert a TF frame if one of the same timestamp already exists, instead just overwrite it.
pr_contents: So, we ran into an issue with ROS on a project (still on kinetic due to legacy robot issues, but this applies to melodic too, so I'll make a similar PR there).

Generally, if a node is broadcasting TF data based on other incoming frames and/or other information, and something goes wrong, it will stop publishing data.  But we ran into a scenario where something went wrong in a node, and it kept broadcasting the same TF data with the same timestamp, forever.  When this happened, we noticed that all nodes with a tf listener started immediately consuming more and more memory.

In looking into this, it is clear that when storing an incoming TF in the tf2 listener code, that if a frame between parent and child exists with the same timestamp, that the incoming data is not ignored, nor does it overwrite the previous frame, but it gets inserted next to the existing frame with the same timestamp, so that now there are multiple transforms between the same two frames with the same timestamp.

I added some debug console outputs and a small publisher node and a node that just makes a tf listener and spins.  This proved that the storage for tf listener does indeed grow infinitely so long as no newer data comes in that is more than max_duration (10 seconds) to force these to be pruned.

The fix is VERY simple, and has been tested with the stand alone programs. where previously the size of storage_ grew without bound when sending the exact same message in a loop, but now remains size 1 for that parent/child transform.

pr_title: Don't insert a TF frame if one of the same timestamp already exists, instead just overwrite it.
pr_contents: So, we ran into an issue with ROS on a project (still on kinetic due to legacy robot issues, but this applies to melodic too, so here's a melodic PR).

Generally, if a node is broadcasting TF data based on other incoming frames and/or other information, and something goes wrong, it will stop publishing data. But we ran into a scenario where something went wrong in a node, and it kept broadcasting the same TF data with the same timestamp, forever. When this happened, we noticed that all nodes with a tf listener started immediately consuming more and more memory.

In looking into this, it is clear that when storing an incoming TF in the tf2 listener code, that if a frame between parent and child exists with the same timestamp, that the incoming data is not ignored, nor does it overwrite the previous frame, but it gets inserted next to the existing frame with the same timestamp, so that now there are multiple transforms between the same two frames with the same timestamp.

I added some debug console outputs and a small publisher node and a node that just makes a tf listener and spins. This proved that the storage for tf listener does indeed grow infinitely so long as no newer data comes in that is more than max_duration (10 seconds) to force these to be pruned.

The fix is VERY simple, and has been tested with the stand alone programs. where previously the size of storage_ grew without bound when sending the exact same message in a loop, but now remains size 1 for that parent/child transform.

pr_title: Add DowngradeAnalyser for reporting non-critical errors
pr_contents: Our robots react on the top-level state of the aggregator. But sometimes we have error which are relevant to know, but not critical at all for operation.
Therefor the DowngradeAnalyser, still report but just be happy.

Looks reasonable to me. Something similar we've experimented with is a folding analyzer— if error X is set, downgrade errors Y and Z, so that there isn't user confusion about which problem to resolve first.

Obviously the whole business of halting operation over diagnostics is in violation of the diagnostics REP, but it's a pretty common pattern, and awfully convenient given that there isn't any other commonly-supported system in ROS for exposing machine consumable component-level status:
I get the concerns indicated in the REP.
But doing it another way probably means implementing an pretty identical layout.

But regardless of that, we have a green/yellow/light on our robot which indicates the diagnostics status. If this is red because of known issues, users will become insensible for the red light and the whole idea is gone.
Does this PR need any more work to get accepted?
It looks good to me, but I'm not the maintainer of this repo, just an interested third party.
what do you think of this DowngradeAnalyser next to the DiscardAnalyser?
This PR attempts to allow mavros to accept
messages from the flight controller or GCS.  This is useful because it can allow a ground station operator to pass the position target to ROS (so that it can do the path planning) without using rviz.

Below is an image of a test using Mission Planner attached to an ArduPilot Rover with ROS running on a tx2.  I was able to select ROS using MP's upper-left vehicle selector and the right-mouse-button-click and select, "Fly To Here".  When mavros consumes the message it converts the latitude, longitude, altitude into ENU and publishes it to /mavros/setpoint_position/cmd_pos topic
Mavros's topic can be remapped to
) so that it can accept the target.

?) can give me a hand in resolving:
Anyway, all feedback is welcome, thanks!

including a couple of videos (
) showing how ROS's path planner can be used as an external navigation source for object avoidance.
, any chance this can be merged?
I'm happy to make changes but I probably need some more specific feedback on what needs changing.
I understand
's comments that we need to be careful of mixing up commands received from a GCS and those received from a vehicle but with
, the position target is now coming from the vehicle.
At the risk of overblowing this minor change, I think it a nice enhancement that allows the flight code to remain in control and only use ROS as a navigation tool when it wants to.

just because something is working for a particular case doesn't mean that we are doing things thr correct way. There is an API and an implementation logic that should always be respected, unless there's nothing we can do besides messing with the API logic.
As you can read on my review, I didn't just referenced the mixing of GCS and FCU messages. I also said that
prefix messages are sent to the flight controller,
coming from it. You can use the counter-part message to get the data from the FCU. Using the

messages here is, as I said, breaking the API and the implementation logic of this package. Doesn't make sense to have a group of messages which usage is respecting the API implementation and then have a case where this is change with no aparent reason.
I'm happy to make changes but I probably need some more specific feedback on what needs changing.
As a reviewer, I gave a specific feedback on what needs to be changed :) I am happy to help you make this implementation correct (not make it work, cause it seems to be).
I understand

's comments that we need to be careful of mixing up commands received from a GCS and those received from a vehicle but with these enhancements to ArduPilot Rover, the position target is now coming from the vehicle.
I wonder if this is correct from the Mavlink API standpoint. Again,
prefixes is something you send from a offboard controller to the FCU, not the other way around.

, thanks again for the feedback.  So the objection is with the SET_TARGET_POSITION_GLOBAL_INT messages coming from the FCU?  I think we haven't had SET_ messages come from the FCU only because we haven't previously tried to make the flight controller the "master".  I.e. the flight controller has always been the "leaf".. it's been pushed around by upper level controllers within ROS.  I don't really see why there would be a restriction on a flight controller providing a position target to ROS's navigation controller... and if we accept that it is OK for a flight controller to provide a position target to ROS, I don't see how it would get it there unless it used the SET_TARGET_POSITION_GLOBAL_INT message (or the very similar SET_TARGET_POSITION_LOCAL_NED)..
.. by the way, I'm very happy to having a voice chat somewhere if that would help speed things along.. we could use
but skype or hangouts or whatever also works for me.

this is not a matter of what has been tried or not. Is what the API is set to do and changing that paradigm first needs a discussion on the Mavlink API. We can't just assume we can use a message in a certain way just becaude it works. Then we would be using all the messages the way we wanted.
You can actually read on the message description the following:
"Used by an external controller to command the vehicle (manual controller or other system)."
If one wants to update the Mavlink protocol API, then one should suggest that same change first, and not apply the message in a certain way that contradicts the API.
Besides really confusing message usage (with it's description),
I'd like to see that as a separate plugin. That should give more clear separation of commanding setpoints
and "guidance receiver" (better to find new name, that will not include
, as they treated as "fly there" command).
Also perhaps that should be in extras, as it have very specific usage.

pr_contents: The solver of ur_kinematics returns solutions in range [0,2PI].

fixes this by generatic the extra solutions in the full range but this adds quite a lot of solutions.
This PR extends

by checking every joint if it is more than 180° away from the seed. If it is, rotating 360° will be beneficial. If the joint limits allow it, the rotation is applied. This always returns the best solutions in the full range of the joint limits.
This, together with
and changing longest_valid_segment_fraction to something lower make ur_kinematics usable with full joint range.

which combines
and
. While this approach is more efficient than the implementation in

If it can be shown by benchmarks that this approach offers a considerable performance improvement over
, then it may be worth using this approach in the single-solution implementation of

would still needed for the multi-solution approach.

This PR changes only searchPositionIK, which is expected to return only one solution, ideally the closest solution to the seed. Moveit uses this function almost exclusively for planning and not getPositionIK.

This implementation does give the closest possible solution to the seed without enumerating every possible but worse extra solutions. By enumerating you are generating 2^6*8 - 8 = 504 extra solutions and sort them without having any benefit for this function.

which is the branch for the PR.

typically outperformed

better, if only by a small percentage, and maybe some would find that valuable.

pr_title: Improving behavior of the planner to follow peak points of the global plan strictly.
pr_contents: Hello Sir,

I have made certain changes to the existing teb_local_planner. It was seen that the teb_local_planner did not follow the peak points of the global plan strictly. It is required because if the teb_local_planner follows the peak points of the global plan strictly, the local planner works more efficiently in terms of time as well as the robot does not get stuck. I have experienced that with the changes made in the code, the robot takes less time than the normal time elapsed to follow the same goal in the existing teb_local_planner.Also, the teb_local_planner does not get stuck in infinite loops of finding an alternative path. In the peakViaPoints( ), I have created a method so that the planner publishes a viaPoint at the peak of the goal plan taken into consideration by the teb_local_planner. Please look forward to the changes I have made.
-- Mudit Jindal
Thank you very much for the proposed changes.
I like the idea to add just significant viapoints instead of using the current naive uniform grid.
However, I have some comments that I would like you to address or discuss before merging.

A general discussion: is it sufficient for most scenarios to find just one peak point or should we try to find all local maxima and local mimima of the curvature of the transformed plan to have all peak points?
Hello,

Local planner should try to find all local maxima and local mimima of the curvature of the transformed plan to have all peak points. All these peak points will act as sub-goals for the local planner which will result in better traceability of the global plan.
Rgds
Nitin
Hello Sir,
I have been a bit busy due to my college exams. Currently trying to move peak-point computation into updateViaPointsContainer. I will update the code in the following week.
Hello,

I have made changes according to ROS C++ styleguide. But cannot find an alternative to change parameters max_number_classes or  enable_multithreading. This is required because max_number_classes while using
, max_number_classes  should be equal to 1. This saves computation cost in terms of time taken to reach the goal.
Moving the method
into
is not required because via points follow the strict order when
is
. Even while using uniform via points with peakViaPoint( ) and
is
, a strict order is followed.

After all I believe your idea in this PR will be useful for people.
Actually I am not the official maintainer of this repository so I can't decide.
But this is the idea: Melodic is LTS and Lunar is not, and people tend to pay more attention to LTS release.

pr_contents: Added some index checking to prevent segfaults
This change is

While I definitely see the value in this, and have been burned by it before, I'm concerned about the computational costs. Have you done side by side comparisons to see how it would affect costmap update loop times?
Also, I feel as though ignoring OOB
s is not the right move, and it should throw an exception, if anything.

We were seg faulting before we added the guards.  To me, not having the robot crash far outstrips any minimal computational cost associated with this.  As a base library that many people use, this should really be the priority.  If there is a more efficient way of doing the check, we can modify to that instead.  We considered changing the type to a std::vector instead, but the delta would be very large.
Sure, I can add a throw for the sets.
I'm also thinking getCost and setCost should not include checks -- and am also concerned about runtime implications -- here's why:
If you look at the existing codebase, pretty much everywhere we call setCost() or getCost() we call worldToMap() first -- so we'd be double checking everything in "normal" operation.

You should probably be using one of the worldToMap functions that includes a check to get your indices before calling getCost/setCost (I am presuming here that you are using costmap_2d in a custom setting, if that's not the case, then we should track down where the proper worldToMap call is missing in this codebase).

There are three different worldToMap functions -- one that just does the calculation, one that does it with bounds checking, and one that does it with checking and constraining the returned values automatically to the range of the cost map. This allows users to decide what level of checking they want to incur cost for.

I would suggest that the docs for getCost() and setCost() should be updated to note this design aspect. And yes, it is a somewhat poorly designed API (in that it is very easy to misuse, as you've found) -- however as you said, fixing the API would be a pretty big delta this late in the game. I'd definitely suggest that we should impress such an update on the navigation2 work (which doesn't end up effecting a large deployed base with such a change right now, and might still have that same API).
+1 to fixing this in navigation2

We are indeed using Costmap in a custom context.  We're doing something similar to setConvexPolygonCost except we are doing the "get" version (with very similar logic).  We call one of the mapToWorld functions to convert the footprint into costmap space and then call convexFillCells to get all the cells in order to calculate the total cost of the footprint.  It's likely the segfault is occuring during some odd corner case where convexFillCells is returning a cell that's out of the costmap indices.  We could put the check outside the getCost function, but it seems to me that a public api should guard itself against segfaults and there shouldn't be a need to translate between world and map frames in order to do that.  We could, of course, do the check outside of the getCost function.  I would however recommend that index checks inside of setConvexPolygonCost remain.
If there is interest, I could PR in our getConvexPolygonCost function as well, modifying to do the check internally instead of in getCost.
pr_details: If you look at the existing codebase, pretty much everywhere we call setCost() or getCost() we call worldToMap() first -- so we'd be double checking everything in "normal" operation.

You should probably be using one of the worldToMap functions that includes a check to get your indices before calling getCost/setCost (I am presuming here that you are using costmap_2d in a custom setting, if that's not the case, then we should track down where the proper worldToMap call is missing in this codebase).

There are three different worldToMap functions -- one that just does the calculation, one that does it with bounds checking, and one that does it with checking and constraining the returned values automatically to the range of the cost map. This allows users to decide what level of checking they want to incur cost for.

originally suggested using a container object to collect all required components of the to-be-attached object. Because in my opinion, this was unrelated to
, I suggested filing these changes as a separate PR.
However, personally, I don't like these changes so much, because in my impression they suggest that the container object will be used as is, which is not the case.
So, I open the discussion for this

Just for the record, this change is only for readability. When I first read through these 150 lines, I kept forgetting/wondering what all these shapes and poses will be used for, and what they refer to (the object from the message? an object in the world? something temporary?). After this change, the intention was clear to me in every line.

and

is too misleading, why not just change it to
or something similar?

as a container actually suggests that this instance will be added, which is not the case.

is almost identical in meaning to me. I considered
etc. but that would make less sense. Maybe adding more explanation would help, as in the in-line comment I just posted?

on its own not too meaningful, and would much prefer
or
to be part of the name.

or similar in
This seems clear to me

I rebased it on master locally and added the comment as a suggestion. It is still good to go. You can either merge after adding the suggestion above or add
as well. I can file another PR if that's easier.

so ugly?", so I renamed the parameter to

to make a distinction between the incoming message and the local mutable object. When I considered this change last year I didn't go through with it because it seemed too verbose, but it might make sense. What do you think?

in
in

returns an

method, as CollisionObjects are mutable, but reusing such a method in robot_state seems inefficient, as there is no need for those objects to be created as an intermediary, and the
is called every time a
is copied. This seems more performance critical than the

pr_contents: I just read through
and
which describe a problem with collision checking of attached objects ending up in self-collision.
I am sorry. I debugged this problem in a hurry already back in October for a demo,
but did not get around to investigate further or create a thread for it.
This patch resolved the problem for me, although it is likely not the best solution.
Without digging deeper into this again, here's what I recall:
The patch addresses this logic bug simply by always allocating the unpadded collision environment.

I am not convinced it is worth the effort to try to fix the lazy allocation scheme here, but I did not benchmark anything and this only becomes relevant when the benchmarks include attach/detach operations...
On top of that, I am not convinced this double-accounting for padded and unpadded checking makes sense anymore(?), but I did not look into the underlying structures deep enough to understand this.
Merging
into
will
coverage by

, I don't see how your explanation and your fix fits my observation of a race condition: When adding a small sleep after a PlanningScene update in MTC's execution capability, the issue is gone.
But, adding a sleep doesn't trigger an extra environment allocation, does it?

I think the right fix would be to find the place where this copy-on-write is broken (ie making a copy is not triggered) instead of removing it? I would expect your changes to have some impact in cases like multi-threaded planners etc.?

if you wait long enough, but sleeping 0.1 seems rather short for that.

helps?

pr_contents: It looks ugly when robots start up in nonsensical poses when running
, and I don't think it should be the default behavior. Setting the robots' initial pose is perfectly possible, but it requires

that users have to look up. This PR changes the behavior of the setup assistant so that if group states (robot poses) are defined in the setup assistant/SRDF, the first one is automatically exported to
as the initial pose of that group.
I believe this will increase discoverability of the feature and be a better default setting.

pr_title: Adding battery voltage information to ROS msg
pr_contents: Recovering feature from v3.2.
I can't find any reason why this feature has been removed in
With this change battery voltage information (V) is provided in topic "/dji_sdk/battery_state". Tested with not DJI original batteries + A3 autopilot.
Hi,
As far as I understand, the old code is vulnerable against spurious wakeups (of the done_condition), allowing the wait_for_result() to return before the done_cb is actually done.
The fix defers the change of SimpleGoalState.DONE (guarding the done_condition), until the done_cb has returned.

pr_title: Removed prefix code which prevented the plugin from being used for mu…
pr_contents: …ltiple arms on one robot. The prefix code does nothing anyway, all it does is check/confirm that the chain contains links for a UR robot, which one can assume outside of this code that it is being used for a UR robot

An alternative suggestion is to instead remove the "return false" from the loops that check the joints which cause the plugin to falsely fail. The plugin still works successfully by reading  the joints from the robot model, and using them in the kdl chain. This redundant checking causes unnecessary failure when using 2+ arms, or by failing to set a prefix (which isn't always 100% necessary)
@ipa-fxm

Edit: I've updated it because the end effector orbs weren't working with the first commit of this pull request. now, it uses the links that are provided by the robot models' kinematic chains rather than pre-defined prefix + hard coded names. This means that you can now set a robot up to use multiple UR-X arms with moveit on a robot.
Before, the plugins would be loaded and limited by a defined arm_prefix parameter, which can only be set to one prefix obviously.

I had it so that i had a left_ur5_arm_ as one prefix for one arm, and right_ur5_arm_ as the prefix for the other, but since the prefix could only be set once before loading a single move_group, it would mean that one planning group could not solve for the other arm, e.g only the left arm in moveit + rviz would be setup correctly, whereas the other would not be found due to the prefix looking for the arm_prefix of the other arm.

Out of curiosity, by checking the moveit configuration packages for the three UR models, all of them use the KDL kinematics plugin by default, which should have no issue with the prefix stuff at all. Why are you using the custom plugin?
You're right, it doesn't. But the custom plugin is way more responsive.
FYI, managed to get this working
Check it out
, thanks for the PR.  I'm a little over my head on this, but it looks good.  Does this have to be an indigo change or could it be a later release.  I'm trying to keep indigo stable.

It's stable on my end and we're going to ship a robot with this code in it. Basically this code pulls the joint names defined by the planning group, which is different if you load a plugin for each arm.

Before, it would use prefix + hard coded UR names, and if you had more than one arm prefix you couldn't use the plugins. When using a left and right arm, you need two prefixes obviously, (left_, right_) and so one of the arms was left to be unable to plan.
While I understand the reason for the change you propose, I'm not sure removing the check is something we necessarily want to do.

An alternative suggestion is to instead remove the "return false" from the loops that check the joints which cause the plugin to falsely fail. The plugin still works successfully by reading  the joints from the robot model, and using them in the kdl chain. This redundant checking causes unnecessary failure when using 2+ arms, or by failing to set a prefix (which isn't always 100% necessary)

The checking may seem redundant, but in reality it tries to make sure that users don't configure it for use with chains that don't contain the expected joints and links. The rest of the code assumes that whatever it receives is a (joint space) pose that it can return sensible answers for. By removing the check and relying on the correctness of the configuration of the chains, we open up the possibility for end-users to configure the use of the plugin for any set of joints and links through the MoveIt Setup Assistant.

(IKFast plugins suffer from the same problem: they are generated for a particular chain, but nothing prevents you from configuring them for an entirely different chain (and not only joints and links, but also their orientation, which can lead to really dangerous situations). The plugin will just assume everything is ok and will return non-sense solutions - which is not immediately obvious.)

Of course this is not completely fool/tamper-proof: any urdf with the same joint & link names will be accepted as ok, even though that is no guarantee that lengths and other properties correspond to what the plugin assumes. There is currently no way for a plugin to communicate for which particular set of joints and links it's capable of solving IK/FK, so it requires knowledge of either the plugin's internals or whatever is the set of joints and links that make up the 'normal' chain the plugin was created for.
I guess ultimately, whether we want to remove this check or not comes down to how
we want to be: do we place the responsibility for proper configuration entirely on the user? Or do we prefer to fail early and warn about misconfiguration?

or
ran into the IKFast-solving-for-whatever-you-give-it issue some time ago. Not sure what the context was anymore.

plugin to work, each should get their own
, which apparently (still) isn't working.

for the other, moveit uses the correct solvers for each group.

So in my opinion - but it really is just my opinion, I'm not even a maintainer here - this PR introduces a potential issue (using it with a chain that does not correspond to the
assumed correct UR configuration) and does not solve the real problem.

Not sure if this ever occurs, but what if a user defines different solver configurations for specific groups/chains? The prefix would be the only way to know for sure that those configurations end up with the correct solver, right?

Right now it pulls all of the joints defined in the group. We can add a check which checks if the subset of these strings contain the valid joints (which would mean every part of the string, nulling the prefix) And then it could accept any prefix, but still hard-define this plugin to make sure it has only the UR joints.

FYI - the referenced issue above is a use case of one of our customers having difficulty with the plugin - not because it is not a UR arm but because the prefix configuration isn't correctly set up. This caused him to use a TRAC IK plugin instead of the work done inside the UR kinematics package - not sure if that is intended.

With this PR, to re-iterate, it would help users just put the ur_kinematics plugin in their .yaml file and then be on their way. As long as they have the 6 UR links/joints defined in their .yaml file and are using the plugin, it'll work with no issues.
any thoughts on getting this merged?
--- FYI we are most likely going to start a new process at CPR for using external repositories;

we will begin by forking a repository (like this one) we wish to modify for our products, make changes, and then release it on our internal ROS distro/system. This way, we can distribute the necessary debian packages and move forward with our lives quickly.
We will then make a PR of the changes we've made - but with minor rush/risk so we can be precise and accurate that the proper changes can be merged into public repositories.
In any case the merge is refused - we will go ahead with our forked branch/release and merge in the features developed here as necessary.
I believe this should help us both in making sure quality code is added - and that we aren't held up by waiting for commits/releases as it is a timely process

pr_contents: Visualization of the costmatrix, where current heading, chosen waypoint and smoothed waypoint are marked. This 2D visualization is very helpful for debugging

The greener the matrix the more costly from a goal or smoothing perspective the cell is. The reder a cell the more expensive it is due to obstacle distance. The darkest cell is the least expensive one. The dark blue cell (here pink because it is in the red area) is current heading, the light blue one currently chosen best cell, the white one the smoothed setpoint which is actually sent to the pixhawk

Not tested on other version of Ubuntu sorry. Yes we can improve the script by checking more efficiently /proc/acpi/power_supply directory, then /sys/class/power_supply, then file in this directory.
An other idea is to install acpi/acpitool package and parse the output
+1 in using acpi/acpitool package. It may give more consistent output in various versions of Ubuntu.
what are your thoughts on this?
Is in my todo list waiting for an opportunity. I'll do on Monday.

's idea is to execute acpitool and recover its text output, right?

When first doing this I think I looked at using acpi/acpitool and wasn't able to get what I wanted as cleanly.  The abstraction might be worth it, but it might end up adding as much complexity as simply catching the known cases.
Right, so I think by now is ok to parse the BAT0 text file. In the future
would be cool to extend this package to provide extra house-keeping laptop
data, as CPU/RAM load, CPU temperature, etc, and maybe then will be time to
use acpi/acpitool.

Hi,
, I'd like to test this newly merged function of yours.
For this, I think I need bag files containing can_info (CAN messages).
I've recorded many bag files which normally include images (from a camera), pointcloud (with a LiDAR) and nmea sentences (by a GNSS); however, they've never had CAN messages yet.
I have my own test vehicle as large as ZMP RoboCar MV2, whose internal communications are all done via CAN.
Would you introduce how to record CAN messages (along with other signals from other sensors)?
FYI, I have the KVASER Leaf as a CAN interface.
Thank you for reading,
Hi,
You need to convert CAN messages to autoware_msgs::can_info by yourself. Autoware does not have any function for the converting.
If you successfully convert and publish them, you can record the can_info topic.
Thanks for your reply, @cirpue49 :)
In vehicle_receiver.cpp, can_info topic is being published -
ros::Publisher can_pub = nh.advertise<autoware_msgs::CanInfo>("can_info", 100);
It tells the ROS master that a message of type autoware_msgs\CanInfo is being published on the can_info topic.
This is followed by
can_pub.publish(can_msg);
, which is included in getCanValue function.
I'm wondering (in getCanValue function) there is no code written to input some (CAN) values to can_msg, which should be implemented as
can_msg.____ = values;
Instead, there are just
can_msg.header.frame_id = "/can";
can_msg.header.stamp = ros::Time::now();
These two are considered very few by comparing with a message of type autoware_msgs\CanInfo; CanInfo.msg contains
Header header
string tm
int32 devmode
int32 drvcontmode
int32 drvoverridemode
int32 drvservo
int32 drivepedal
int32 targetpedalstr
int32 inputpedalstr
float64 targetveloc
float64 speed

int32 targetshift
int32 inputshift
int32 strmode

int32 stroverridemode
int32 strservo
int32 targettorque
int32 torque
float64 angle
float64 targetangle
int32 bbrakepress
int32 brakepedal
int32 brtargetpedalstr
int32 brinputpedalstr
float64 battery
int32 voltage
float64 anp
int32 battmaxtemparature
int32 battmintemparature
float64 maxchgcurrent
float64 maxdischgcurrent
float64 sideacc
float64 accellfromp
float64 anglefromp
float64 brakepedalfromp
float64 speedfr
float64 speedfl
float64 speedrr
float64 speedrl
float64 velocfromp2
int32 drvmode
int32 devpedalstrfromp
int32 rpm
float64 velocflfromp
int32 ev_mode
int32 temp
int32 shiftfrmprius
int32 light
int32 gaslevel
int32 door
int32 cluise
Please be more specific on how to input values to can_msg.
I'd appreciate you, @cirpue49!

pr_title: show charging progress on led ring
pr_contents: Will this node set the lights all the time? What's the priority compared to e.g. emergency_stop_monitor or application_triggered light?
This node will set the lights only during charging process. The priority is set to default, so every other node is able to override the lights with a higher priority.

pr_title: Add manual control state and functors
pr_contents: This change is

The sdk check and battery percent check are present in many functors.  Is there a way we can condense this functionality to avoid duplicate code?  Ex: we can create some base functor that implements the functionality and other functors that need the safety checks can derive from it.
Reviewed 18 of 18 files at r1.
Review status: all files reviewed at latest revision, 3 unresolved discussions.
whats this for?
can we call this enableAutonomousMode or something instead?  I think that is more clear
Don't you have to enter manual mode first with flowControl(false) or something before seeing if you can leave manual mode?

Added a base functor which checks for the low battery and SDK closed option. It generates land and Abort events for these. I cannot use it with takeoff internal action functor since I have to generate a manual control event instead of an Abort event. But its still useful for position control and visual servoing internal action functors.
Review status: 13 of 19 files reviewed at latest revision, 3 unresolved discussions.
whats this for?
This is to increase the number of entries allowed in transition table of boost state machine. By default it is set to 20 and the latest code changes have 21 entries so I had to increase this limit.
can we call this enableAutonomousMode or something instead?  I think that is more clear
Done.
Don't you have to enter manual mode first with flowControl(false) or something before seeing if you can leave manual mode?

Assume you are in ManualControlState and we flipped the RC switch to SDK control, the test checks that the internal action functor triggers the right event based whether quadrotor is in air or already landed.

pr_contents: Please review,
Additional MCU msgs/srvs (to be documented on the jackal_firmware ROS wiki page):
nmea_msgs/Sentence -> raw strings to and from globaltop module
sensor_msgs/IMU -> raw data from accelerometer and gyro
geometry_msgs/Vector3Stamped -> raw magnetometer data
std_srvs/Empty -> enable_motors, stop_motors services
std_msgs/Bool (?) -> wifi connected status
MCU parameters to be reviewed separately.
Placeholder for MCU firmware comments:
sensor_msgs/IMU isn't meant for truly raw data. Will need to determine where is best to scale to m/s^2, etc
I like going from least complex to most. So, PWM, then SPEED, then TORQUE
The reason it's as it is so that speed is the default. This ordering is "order of likelihood that it's what you want".

If we're always going to be sync'd between motors (which we should be), should we make that clear in this part by explicitly creating left_* and right_* members? IMO it'll be easier than arrays when using CLI tools to monitor
Based on my experience with Grizzly, it comes in handy having them be arrays rather than named members. It's a lot easier to assign names to the members than it is to produce an array after the fact.
Is "drivers_active" the enabled status? Otherwise known as the "/ESTOP"?
Yes, but I'd prefer to avoid "estop" terminology, since it isn't really one.
If we change the message period, are we going to autoadjust this in in firmware (as in, is it worth the trouble)? Maybe just say "1 Hz" for the average

It's easier to go by publish period than to say that it will always be a 1sec average. (ie, someone changes the period to 5Hz for some reason, then you need to track 5 separate averages-in-progress, ugh)
For which voltage level? If we're talking all voltages, what's the use you've got in mind? IMO a "lowest battery voltage" would be more usable for diagnosing brownouts.

VBATT—I believe all the currents are being measured upstream of the respective regulators, and it's VBATT feeding the PC and motor drivers. The use is to alert the user of overall system current spikes which may not be visible in the 1Hz averages. I agree that lowest-seen voltage would be useful as well.
An alternative way to do this would be to define a CurrentFeedback message with avg, peak, variance, whatever, and then use instances of those in this message. I'm not sold either way.
Where do we report MCU uptime?
Should be here. That's missing, thanks.
re: sensor_msgs/IMU
The intent is that the MCU will publish a data message suitable for consumption by
, using standard REP-103 units.
So, scaling will occur on the MCU, controlled by rosparams.

pr_title: BUS VOLTAGE: widen window for bus voltage estimate
pr_contents: The window seems a little big to me. We're really still looking to just throw out an outlier reading right? We still want to kill pretty quickly if the battery is actually low.

The bus voltage actually drops momentarily during transient periods with high thrust output, but then recovers after it. It's more like something to filter transient periods than a single reading outlier remover.

The way I understand our batteries (which could be completely wrong) is that there is a cutoff voltage where we should stop using them. Even if they only dip below that voltage while moving, isn't that still bad for the batteries in the long term?
We can ask

what the optimal value is. I think as it is right now, there is a safety margin above that value where it is harmful for the batteries. I've had the sub kill at about 45.5 volts because it momentarily dipped below 44 volts (kill voltage).
Merging since there have been no further comments, and we can always just modify the kill voltage.

pr_contents: This is the completed dashboard for RQT. It currently displays kill status, operating mode, battery voltage, system time, and the IP and network status of all network enabled devices on Navigator. It also has a control panel that implements most of the functionality of the X-Box controller (actual keyboard driving of the boat is in the works).

Test day was a surprisingly good time for edge case testing and I was able to take care of all of the ones I found while the boat was in a state of chaos, so it should be fairly stable. If any additional display or control features are needed, just ask. I made it very simple to implement new ones.
Looks mostly good. Before I merge though, we need to figure out a system to station hold the boat with the newest version of lqrrt.
, can you post the new station holding command here?
Create and alarm broadcaster and raise the
alarm

I just had a few more questions to make sure we are on the same page here. Does the alarm get cleared once the system enters station holding? Should the KillBroadcaster and SetBool parts of the station holding function be removed? What severity should be used (I went with a severity of 1, allowing something in the priority queue to supersede it while still keeping it fairly high)?

Point noted. The language in the alarms page of the Sub8 wiki is a little confusing on the issue in that it makes it sound like the severity is used internally: "When many alarms must be handled, they will be handled as a priority queue...."
This is good to merge once Semaphore checks out. I would like to get it on dev before Sunday so that we don't have to go through all of my relaunch shenanigans again.
Semaphore is asleep :(
I agree getting this in dev is important
pr_details_more: The
alarm gets automatically cleared whenever the boat starts station holding.
KillBroadcaster and the SetBool service are a thing of the past

The severity is ignored internally. It is used right now only for human assessment of a situation, ie. seeing an alarm went off and not knowing what the alarm means but based on the severity, determining if it is important or not. All alarms are dealt with with equal importance. With that being said, I would make it 3 so that the user shouldn't have to worry about that alarm.

pr_title: `move_base_interruptable_server` seems to be causing `move_base` to crash
pr_contents: Seems to happen when
tries to call
, but only sometimes.
I'm in the processes of investigating why this happens.
I did a little more investigating this morning, including capturing a core dump (thanks for the tip,
First, I'm not actually sure that this is a problem with
. I'll leave the title of this PR as-is for now, but it may need to be updated going forward. The reason I say this is because I rebuilt after commenting out a large portion of
and the problem didn't go away.
I'm now thinking that this could possibly be a bug within the ROS navigation stack itself. I ran our

node in GDB in a separate terminal, and, after a long while (I'm still unsure as to how to reliably reproduce this bug, which is worrisome), found Leela motionless at a door with the following output in the
terminal  (entire core dump is available on Leela at

Obviously, the backtrace here wouldn't be able to implicate any of our BWI code even if it was at fault, but the fact that the error occurs so many levels deep is why I wonder if this is some kind of bug in the ROS navigation stack. Specifically, I wonder about the
code, which is implicated in the lowest-level frames.
I'm not exactly sure what the path forward is at this point, so I'm open to suggestions. Perhaps next I'll try switching our
's
from
back to the default
to see if that makes a difference.
At first glance, there seems to be enough information to open an issue in
It's probably worth checking whether
is related.
, that does seem like it could be very related! Though we don't seem to get that exact warning message. I suppose to test this, we'd have to compile our own navigation stack from source and use that.
Another theory I've had is that this somehow related to the way we (BWI) deal with the map. Specifically, when monitoring Leela during
, I've noticed that the map seems to refresh after every completed goal. Further, these crashes are only occurring

the goal locations themselves (doors). Is there perhaps some kind of weird race condition cropping up here where the planner is trying to use a costmap that has temporarily been deleted because it's being replaced by some other BWI process?
, are you able to comment on this?
OK, I tried out switching the global planner to
today, and Leela ran without issue until the battery gave out.
Assuming this passes further testing, this would seem to indicate that our issue might be specific to the
code, or at least the particular way we interact with it.
I want to test this out a few more times in order to make sure this has really resolved our issue.
I also want the extra test runs in order to make sure Leela actually navigates smoothly in the hallways: I already found, for instance, that I needed to remove the
line in
in order for it to not get "stuck" sometimes.
Tested this for a few more hours today and all seems well: Leela seemed to run smoothly and without crashing.
So I'm going to go ahead and merge this into
I'm also going to open another pull request, perhaps destined to last a very long time, to figure out how we can switch back to
. There, we could, for example, try building the latest navigation stack from source and see if recent changes have fixed this or if we can track down the bug ourselves.

Adds data subscribers for RobotState (battery voltage, faults, CAN metrics, etc) and for JoyFeedback (joystick rumble). RobotState data is displayed on the UI, JoyFeedback data is currently unused since joysticks are not yet supported.

pr_title: Added remove_crazyflie service to Crazyflie driver
pr_contents: Added a service to remove a Crazyflie.

The new service disconnects and remove a Crazyflie which allows to add it again later. This is added to be able to run continuous demo and, for example, change battery of a Crazyflie without restarting the complete system.
Thanks! I was always wondering why that is useful, but this is a pretty cool use-case. Also, with your changes it should now be possible to do a proper clean-up when the server exits.

pr_title: Added timeout to logblock stop in Crazyflie_cpp
pr_contents: If Crazyflie is switched-off while connected, the Crazyflie object locks on removing log block if it is deleted.
This commit adds a timeout of 50 packets to remove a log block.

Hi Arnaud, Thanks for your pull request. I have another branch (requestBatching), which adds a much better handling of the communication, including timeouts for all communication. However, the "downside" is that it actually throws an exception in case a timeout occurs, which seems not the desired behavior in your case. Do you have any thought on when exceptions are reasonable and when not?

For now, I can merge this, since it seems to be a good change for your remove/add Crazyflie use-case. In the future, I want to merge the requestBatching branch and would like to prevent "surprises" which might be created by thrown exceptions.
Thanks!
Hi Wolfgang, I agree a more generic way would be better but since this allowed me to fix my problem I though I would share it. Thanks for merging!

As for the exception, as long as the crazyflie_server does not die it will not break my use case. One problem I actually have is that if I remove a Crazyflie for more than a second all topics from this Crazyflie will freeze and will reappear only about 12 seconds after the Crazyflie is re-added. To mitigate that I remove and add the Crazyflie quickly which seems to work (and it makes it even more important to be able to remove a disconnected Crazyflie, since I will change the battery before removing the crazyflie from ROS). I am guessing this is happening because I am not using ROS topics the way it is suppose to by removing/re-adding topic dynamically.
Fix a column order of battery info
In the case of pr2's battery is NA, we cannot calculate the remained percentage of capacity.
これはNAがあるとどうなるの？表示されない？プログラムが落ちなく成る？喋らなくなる？？？？

pr_contents: This pull request is a forum for discussing what still needs to be done to support all our existing robot models from a unified source tree.
When these items and any others we discover have been resolved, we can do the merge and delete the segbot2 branch.
: comments?
Unfortunately, there are currently 73 changed files.

To save time, most of you can probably skim the segbot_firmware modifications. They were never fully integrated into the old code base. The same is true of the Arduino driver interface in segbot_sensors.
So, the changes with the most impact are in the .launch and .yaml files, including navigation and filters. There are not many of those.
I'm looking at this right now. I think there are a couple of issues with amcl that I need to investigate. I think segbot 1 and segbot 2 require different parameters.
This PR has been subsumed by
pr_details_more: merge segbot_navigation/new_lazer branch into its master
regression test on a segbot1 (bender)
regression test again on a segbot2 (roberto)
install additional dependency on all the segbots and lab machines:
clean up segbot2 branch, when no longer needed (

pr_title: GUI: add GUI for voltage monitoring
pr_contents: Good work! I think it would be more useful if there were labels next to each voltage display saying what it is instead of the kinda awkard one in the upper right. This would be easy (and a lot of the code would be cleaner) if you defined that layout in QtCreater and created a ui file like in our main GUI. This would put all the inserting widgets and setting their positions in a XML file so your code is just the interface to ROS
Created XML File and easier to read interface
Great work on this! Thanks for the refactor to use the UI file. Please remove any "dead" code that isn't needed anymore. Also be sure to fix your
, as we don't merge code with formating issues. You can check it locally using
Two more things I noticed in testing:
Everything should be Pep8 clean. Deleted unnecessary code. The program checks the params for battery-voltage/critical and battery-voltage/low every three seconds until they have been set.
pr_details_more: the voltages come in with like 10 digits of precision, you should round it to 2 so it doesn't look weird
the paramters for critical / low should be

pr_title: fixing flip_ins not removed if gateway disconnects
pr_contents: Please check it and merge if you are happy with it.
Seems to work fine for me after a day of testing dropping network and putting back on in VM.
Existing Tests are fine too.
We might want to reduce the watcher gone timeout. Not sure what is the point of keeping a flip, that we know has been disconnected already...
Changelog :
[rocon_gateway] not removing flips on shutdown to have similar behavior
[rocon_gateway] deleting old flips when flipping again, in case.
[rocon_gateway] not unregistering gateway on shutdown to have similar behavior if error
[rocon_hub] simplify gateway unavailable/dead to have only one state "gone"
[rocon_hub_client] small fix to trigger update and exit quickly on shutdown
Only one small thing : the existing "flips" from the origin gateway are still duplicated in Redis, but it doesn't seem to have any harmful effect from what I could observe.
The behavior when dropping that gateway after long time absent (timeout 300) doesn't seem to be correct.
This usually happens :
More fixes have gone in, most notably some redesign to make sure the gateway rewrite it s data into redis if the hub eventually decides to drop it.

pr_contents: will show current voltage by this PR.
I tested with real PR2.
what kind of battery estimation(?) can you get from this voltage information?
I mean, how should we read this voltage information?
The original problem is sudden shutdown of computer on real robot.
I suspect that this might be caused by low voltage of batteries.
The voltage of batteries on PR1040 measured on 2019/5/17 18:04:51, only a few seconds before sudden shutdown, was below.
Design voltage is 14.4V, but I don't know how much voltage is really needed for computer to work (according to the above list, it may be ~13.4V ???).
So voltage information added in this PR is just for debugging.
Robot should speak warning messages when low voltage, so I will work on this feature in
travis test is failing because indigo is alreay EOL.
Please restart build after
is merged.

pr_title: Separation of driver and controller (yaml + launch)
pr_contents: all changes carried out for every robot affected (cob3's, cob4's, raw's, desire)
needs to be tested with hardware!
The concept of separation does not hold smoothly for the components where the driver also provides controller interfaces (e.g. frida, head_axis, prace_grippers, schunk_sdh, ur)
The launch file syntax only allows to evaluate true/false using if/unless. You can not check whether a  string has a value set or whether it is empty.
Thus, I suggest to use component_solo only to bring up the drivers and - if set to true - also start the cob_trajectory_controller.
component_solo.launch does not work for all components anyway due to different launch file arguments required by the drivers (robot_ip, ur_ip, ...)
all cob_bringup tests passed!
visual review: OK
latest commits include:
tested with raw3-3 hardware
one remaining issue is still
whether the parameter module_ids: [] from X_driver.yaml in cob_hardware_config
is required by canopen_driver.launch
Visual Review: OK
pr_details_more: add controller directory containing pure controllers (for the moment that's only trajectory_controller.launch)
add an argument controller with default="" to component_solo.launch
rename schunk_powercube_chain.launch to schunk_powercube_chain_driver.launch
rename voltage_controller.launch to battery_voltage.launch
rename voltage_filter.launch to batter_voltage_filter.launch
component_solo for canopen components
several merges with raw3-3 development (e.g.

I think this script works when
has a state named
. But for now STARO and HRP2JSKNTS do not have a such state, and I got the following two ideas.
The first one looks better, but battery infromation has no relationship with hrpsys...
Do you have any suggestions?
in hrpsys. battery status is published already in some topic?
Currently, not.
However, before implement it into hrpsys-base, we need to discuss
which information should be used as battery status.
On pr2, what does battery status include?
a lot
I think we do not need to fill all the fields of the BatteryServer.
PR2のバッテリーの仕組みがわかってきた気がしますが，
hrpsysがバッテリー情報をpublishする部分はどうするのが正しいのでしょうか？
「hrpsysを挟む」ことを考えずに，/battery/serverのtopicを出すだけのPRは作れそうですが，こちらを作ってよいでしょうか？

電源に関する何かしらのプログラムがｃでもｖでもどちらでもOKとすると、
いろいろ依存関係やOSのバージョンなど考慮して、ｃよりｖの方が管理がラクなように思います。
僕のイメージだと，基盤があって，それが現在の電圧，電流，残り時間を出してくれて，readするだけでよくて，それがioボード経由か
シリアル／USB経由かはわからないけど，そういう状況にているので，電源に関するプログラム，というのは存在しなくて，readするだけ．
hrpsysのエマージェンシーは議論が続いている気がするけど，電源低下もその一種なのでこれが起こればemergencyとして，
サーボオフするなり，warningだすなりする機能が考えられる．エンコーダのトビがあったら止まる，とか，バランスを崩していたら止まる，
とか，足裏が擦れていたら止まるとか，そういうのは最下層のプログラムで行われるべき事柄．コリジョンチェックも最下層で行われている．
そのデータはros経由でパブリッシュされてなんか見ることはできるだろうし，そのパブリッシュされた結果をみて中するプログラムもあるだろうけど，それは色々可能性がある．
最下層のプログラムは，落ちたら終わりなので，かなり丁寧に作ってデバッグも最優先．
それ以外の上のプログラムはまぁ落ちてもよいかというレベル．
電源は最下層部分だろうから（とはいえ電源がないときに何ができるかは，ないかもしれないけど），それは最下層の部分に入れておくべき．
現状のシステムで最下層はhrpsys本体．ROSの通信がつながらない，外部のPCのホスト名が引けない，いろいろあったとしても，体内のCは
動き続けていることが期待される．
電源は論理的に最下層だけど，実装として最下層部分とは違うシステムで動いているのは，再優先で作って置かなければいけない最下層部分を
広げることになって手間が増えるだけなので破綻する．
とはいえarduinoのボードで作っていて自分で通信をちゃんと書ける人はそんなにいないだろうから，rosserialでつくってjsk_common/jsk_arduion_apps
みたいにあたして，温度管理のarduino基盤のプログラムと共に置いておくのでいいともいますが，
新しい電源管理ボードは長期的と言っても１ヶ月もないと思います．

pr_title: BATTERY: ignore voltage readings if fault
pr_contents: Pretty python! Just want to be sure that the motors do report a fault before they start reporting inaccurate voltages
I went over to CIMAR with David for kill testing (buttons work again woo!) and did some more verification of how the motor controllers respond to kills / off batteries. Heres what I learned:

So this probably means that the fault code won't be that reliable for detecting kill, because we command a zero thrust on kill, which seems to cause them to not fault correctly. I think the best way is to monitor hw-kill alarm and ignore all readings if it is raised. While you're there though, maybe we should create a new thruster-fault alarm that raises when a thruster fault is engaged with the parameters having a nice string decoding of the byte
yay hardware
pr_details_more: When the battery powering a thruster is off (front for left battery, rear for rear battery), the thruster reports the undervoltage fault
When thrusters are being commanded a significant thrust, undervault fault IS reliably reported on kill

When a thruster is not being commanded a thrust or is commanded a very small thrust (<10), undervault fault IS NOT raised reported on killed. The voltage reading becomes inaccurate and trends towards zero, but the fault is not seen

pr_title: Fix for stuck in place rovers
pr_contents: Rovers would get stuck in the ROTATE state of the statemachine inside DriveController.cpp .  The values being passed out of the fastPID method were too low (varied from 40 all the way to 0 or 1).  The net result was the rover would send these through ROSAdapter into sendDriveCommand resulting in constant power to motors but the rover wouldn't move.  The fix was to set a hard min value for rover motor speeds coming out of fastPID inside the ROTATE state.  Currently set to 80 and seems to run ok.  Needs testing.  Made changes to PID.cpp and ROSAdapter.cpp with cleaning up and commenting all 3 files and moving some braces for readability while debugging problem.  Currently left debugging cout statements in code for future hardware testing.  Will remove once testing is complete before pull request is accepted.
Actual fix located in DriveController.cpp on lines 139-171
Fixes issue
1.) Rover no longer gets stuck while turning
None
None
I mischecked the review response. This pull request is ready for merging!

This pull will add a motor step function in abridge. This causes the robot to change speed by a maximum value per frame. As speed changes are limited it is now difficult to ask for a speed change that would cause an over current event.

It may still be possible by taking a joystick and twirling it in a circle as fast as possible asking for rapid left right and forward reverse commands simultaneously. However this is a useless maneuver and thus is deliberately attempting to break the robot as this does not work in auto-mode.
Can you tell me what problems you've seen that this fixes?

Looking at your patches I see that you've limited the slew rate to 75 codes per frame and removed the maximum speed of 120 (now it seems to be back to 255). Do you have any data on the maximum slew rate?
please respond to
's question. Thanks.
First I found a bug that needs fixing before this can be accepted

Second, this fixes a problem where the robot rapidly commands a change in direction and this causes the motors to draw larger than normal amounts of current. As a result the self-resting fuse built into the PCB trips and cuts motor power essentially freezing a robot in place until motor commands stop long enough for it to cool down and reset.

Since auto runs at 10 frames per second this limits a -255 to 255 speed change to roughly 7 frames or 7/10ths of a second. However changes to a speed of 0 will be one frame as usually after I fix the bug
I will test it after the change is made. I should basically let it run for about 30 minutes and see if the rover freezes, correct?
, yes. Be sure to test the joystick control, keyboard control, and autonomous driving.
