pr_contents: Based on the discussions in
we have prepared a new version of the interface switching.
@ipa-fxm has prepared a gazebo plugin that uses this interface, you can find it here:
(source+documentation)
I like the signature you propose for
. It's more complete than my original proposal:

Having knowledge of the controllers to stop (and not only of those to start) is relevant, as one might want to take action on resources that become free. For instance, one might want to switch a joint to an idle, low-power, or safe mode.
I'm not so fond of
's signature:
To me, the purpose of this method (or
, as it was before) is to verify whether
can be successfully performed, without actually switching anything. I'm expecting the method parameters to be similar. I see two downsides to the proposed signature:
Even if the required logic implied by
is longer, it provides stronger consistency guarantees. Also,
should be then made aware of the strictness policy.
OK, sounds reasonable.
The entire
method runs in non real-time, so it should be OK.
I see your point with inter-controller mode dependencies, but I came to the conclusion that those are rare cases and can be handled in checkForConflict as well.
The main issue here is the best-effort switching.
To really support this inter-controller checking with best-effort, we need a rather complicated interface:
In addition start_request_ and stop_request_ must be updated based on the result, which introduces multiple iterations on all of these lists.
In particular the RobotHW implementor must pay attention to:
I prefer the simpler interface, because it is less error-prone.
It is not full-featured, but should be sufficient for most cases.
We have a couple of options now:
If you really want to go for the 4th option, you are more than welcome to provide a working implementation.
I started to write one, but the effort didn't justify the benefit for me.
I guess it would be easier to rewrite the ControllerManager from scratch with proper look-up tables and interfaces..
Anything new here?
Which API are we going to use eventually?
I'll give some feedback before the end of the week.

Initial disclaimer: I expect to have slow response times until mid-April, but will try to stay in the loop as much as possible. Development efforts from my side will likely have to wait until this date.
By looking at the
code again, I realized that
does not take the strictness parameter into account, it's actually always strict. If it did, the complications raised by
in his
would also apply to it.
So, we can say from the existing implementation that

. If now, for consistency's sake, we apply the same reasoning to the mode switching code, then the problem becomes much more tractable. I'm sorry for the noise introduced by trying to fit in the strictness parameter, I just hadn't made the above simple realization.
If
is strict, I believe we could then get away with these signatures:
What do you think?.
We are fine with strict canSwitch, I will issue a new PR with this interface as soon as I can :)
One last question: Should restarted controllers be filtered out? Otherwise the RobotHW implementation needs to take care.
One last question: Should restarted controllers be filtered out? Otherwise the RobotHW implementation needs to take care.

Yes, why not. Having it in a single place instead of in every specialized RobotHW will save code. Anyway, if you see some inconvenience along the way you can defer the filtering to RobotHW. Switching a resource to the mode it's currently on should not be hard to handle.
Thanks for offering to prepare the PR. I greatly appreciate the effort you're putting into this.
I guess this PR can be closed, too, as
is merged!
pr_quotes: One last question: Should restarted controllers be filtered out? Otherwise the RobotHW implementation needs to take care.
pr_details_more: Conflicts between controllers (and their interfaces) can be checked in checkForConflict

New member canStart checks if the given controller can be started (including HW interface switches) from the current state. For strict checking the switch fails if one controller cannot be started, otherwise it is filtered out.
We assume that controllers can be stopped at any time
After all checks are passed  new member doSwitch is called with filtered lists of controllers that start or stop, but not restart
All controller information needed for switching is contained in ControllerInfo
canStart was chosen in favour of the discussed canSwitch, because this simplifies the filtering and handling in general
doSwitch only gets updates, not the the full list, this should simplify the handling of stopped interfaces
doSwitch runs in the non-RT part, do you see any pros or cons for running it in the real-time part?

It checks controllers individually. Certain inconsistent configurations can only be detected with full knowledge of the end controller configuration. The previously discussed example of a differential transmission illustrates it. Two different controllers might want to use one joint of a differential each, but in different joint modes. Your hardware might not be able to support this.

pr_title: Split robot specific parameters into separate yaml
pr_contents: This PR creates a separate yaml file for the robot-specific parameters in the navstack (e.g. specific to turtlebot3 waffle model) and integrates it alonside
in the launch files. For different robot yaml files, they can be specified at command line via
I've left out changes to the
since it is currently incurring run-time failures due to ExecuteProcess and rosargs for params.
So I get what you were going for, but in practice, they really are
robot specific parameters. The number of samples Vx and Vy are also substantially related to the speed and controller frequency on the base, as well as the costmap sizes, etc.

I'm not sure I agree. Perhaps I should be more precise to say that I am aiming to separate robot characteristics or properties from tuneable algorithm parameters. Though you might change the number of samples Vx and Vy based on your robot's properties, I'd argue those are parameters to tune of the algorithm, not characteristics of the robot itself.

I'd say if your robot is 2 meters tall and a meter wide, then the size of the costmap is a robot-specific parameter, or if your robot is ackermann vs. differential drive, the Vx/Vy samples might be robot drivetrain specific.

Having 2 different files of parameters for a single program seems like it could be confusing. Someone looks at one file, makes the changes and is none the wiser that others exist. I think for grouping purposes if you're trying to group parameters in not a mega-file, separating parameters by program.
Traditionally configuration files for sp. packages are in different files for more portability. Ei my AMCL params are in another file than my costmap_2d parameters, from my DWB parameters, etc

In concept I dont mind organizing parameters differently, but if we move some params of [node A] we should probably move all the params of [node A] so that they're all together. Realistically over time I really do mess with all of them, since you don't actually (or at least me) tell DWB it can go as fast as the robot base is capable of since I dont want robots going 5 m/s next to humans

I'd say if your robot is 2 meters tall and a meter wide, then the size of the costmap is a robot-specific parameter, or if your robot is ackermann vs. differential drive, the Vx/Vy samples might be robot drivetrain specific.

I don't disagree that these parameters are influenced by the robot's properties, but I see them as tuneable, whereas the properties I'm suggesting to split would be innate (for the most part) to the robot itself.

Having 2 different files of parameters for a single program seems like it could be confusing. Someone looks at one file, makes the changes and is none the wiser that others exist. I think for grouping purposes if you're trying to group parameters in not a mega-file, separating parameters by program.

I thought this model with more than one file logically grouped was more convenient. I was considering either to remove the default robot parameters file from launch to enforce users to be precise about their robot and/or to block or error out the program if certain key robot parameters were not present in the yaml file. I'd argue that there may not be any sensible default that covers all robots, therefore we shouldn't allow the stack to progress (i.e. if no robot radius or footprint was specified).
Traditionally configuration files for sp. packages are in different files for more portbility. Ei my AMCL params are in another file than my costmap_2d parameters, from my DWB parameters, etc

In concept I dont mind organizing parameters differently, but if we move some params of [node A] we should probably move all the params of [node A] so that they're all together. Realistically over time I really do mess with all of them, since you don't actually (or at least me) tell DWB it can go as fast as the robot base is capable of since I dont want robots going 5 m/s next to humans

I'd think a parameter to limit max speed for the controller (in consideration for safety/humans) could be a dwb-specific parameter. Yes, I had originally thought to separate out yaml files by stack module, but there were some implementation considerations given how we do parameter substitutions in the yaml.
I think it would make sense to move what lets call
, which I think are fairly ill-defined, into a specific yaml file would make sense if we were going back to to having some utility or server
that all of the nodes query for those parameters such that there is no redundancy and they are parameters that are uniquely hardware specific
Here's how I hoped this would play out over time.
After splitting out parameters that describe the physical characteristics of the robot (the

) We could then relate the other parameters back to those basic ones. Maybe they are just rough guidelines at first but eventually, we could perhaps compute them in some way, reducing the number of parameters users need to tweak.
Those examples you listed out - maybe we could provide guidelines that say, for example, the costmap size should be
or something like that. That is, relate all the algorithm tuning parameters back to fundamental parameters in some way.

if the longer term plan is to do that, then I think that it should be included here, right now, otherwise its a separation of information based on the promise of something in the future that no one's created a ticket and committed to working on actively. Keep in mind in the last few weeks the majority of my work here has been either reverting or refactoring code to fix problems of "we'll do this thing" that then never happens. I'd very much so like to stop that and start working on some of the motion planning work I'd like to have replace NavFn. As it stands in the PR, its separating parameters that

be physical values, but generally aren't (I dont know anyone actually sets their max robot speed in planners, or else there would be clearpath robots at 2m/s in shopping malls), from the rest of a packages settings.

ehhh.... I can see where you're going with that, but I'm not buying it as a way of removing parameters. Maybe give some "first guess" defaults, but doing something like that doesn't replace the need for the parameterization so it seems to be a bit extraneous. Could not be there at all and I dont know that its missing anything, could also be a markdown readme formula for someone to get started, could be code as you suggest
I'm just not seeing the benefit of organizing in this way unless there's something in someone's immediate queue  to implement a robot package-like server or these parameters are central to
packages and having another file would let us reduce duplication.
it was actually very much the original idea to put these parameters on a separate server node. For now, we held off on the parameter server given discussions on
and in issue
about remaining parameter features and design proposals needed for support. I saw this PR as a step in that direction, starting by identifying ownership of certain parameters.

If you're concerned about having a different limit on some parameters such as max velocity on a robot for a controller implementation, I would set that as a separate parameter in the controller node and keep the physical property separate with the robot parameters, because you could cap the velocity at the lowest between the two (if say, I have a slower robot). Semantically, there is a difference between the max "safe" velocity we'd ever allow in our controller (or perhaps "safe" depends on context) vs the max velocity the robot can nominally achieve. Given their semantic difference, I'd perhaps use two parameters. If we could think of parameters in these semantic terms maybe it'll be easier to decide where they should live.

Also, while I agree we shouldn't promise work that never gets done, I think the first step is to determine whether said thing is worth doing and with what importance. So if we should make a ticket to automate parameter tuning, then we should go for it and place it somewhere in our priority queue :)
Given their semantic difference, I'd perhaps use two parameters
But why? the existing parameter is the max speed
, not for the robot. No where in the stack to my understanding is a parameter for the robot's maximum speed. I think you may be reading the phrase
in some global sense as the maximum speed of the robot rather than its actual use
, the maximum speed for the dwb planner.

What function would there be in having the actual maximum robot velocity around in this codebase? No where here to my knowledge would need it. These aren't hardware limits, they're limits for individual packages and programs to use in computing their tasks. industrial robots can achieve dangerously fast speeds that are completely impractical (3 m/s) and even having that in software for someone to make the mistake of using it could be dangerous, unless there's a specific case where that is needed to compute some derivative value, but I'm not seeing any evidence of that.

I understand what the intent is, but I think there's some misreading what these parameters mean to the packages that define them, rather than some global parameter of robot dynamics. Lets play out that we have some
that hosts a set of parameters about the robot, with the exception of
in the
, none of the parameters have utility for other components in the existing stack. I'm not seeing strong evidence that the centralized parameter server serves too much of a purpose beyond setting
since the overlap seems to only be a parameter that happens to exist under the scope of a package executable which is instantiated twice.
I super love the idea of a
but I think that involves some substantial redesign of the stack that we're not totally prepared to do, which is in large part why I nuked the
package (and even then, we've now nuked 3/4 of the utility functions that survived)

I'll buy that for most industrial robots you would not approach those speeds/hardware limits, but I think there's the use case that some arbitrary robot may have limits that are not congruent with the defaults in the code. Even so if maintaining just the one parameter, per robot, there may be some parameters that are configurable by type of robot, which is why I proposed the logically grouping by robot as opposed to by the controller algorithm. I'm not really trying to argue specific parameters (like maximum robot velocity), but rather the justification of a logical grouping, where it seems I see the benefit and you don't so far.

On the robot server, I'd say looking ahead, if we are introducing new planners, controllers, maps, and plugin interfaces to the stack, I think moving towards a split robot parameters file would help us remove duplication and maintain modularity. I have a branch on my fork where I actually did experiment with a robot server/parameter blackboard concept and it wouldn't take too much modification to our stack.

Sorry, yes, I think I've fixated on the velocity as an example since the proposed file changes represent 3 major classes of parameters: speed limits, footprint size, acceleration limits. Speed and acceleration limits both follow the logic I have above so I thought it was a pretty representative example.
if we are introducing new planners, controllers, maps, and plugin interfaces to the stack

This is true, and if/when that happens I can see a stronger argument for having a set of robot-specific parameters around, however that still doesn't change the fact that any new package will include their own parameters, so now there's 2 different organizations of things to maintain and look between. You still have these parameters namespaced to their respective nodes

so they're still not portable, the file would need to be updated to reflect those changes in packages so that kind of nulls out that benefit. Another point is that if these are truly robot specific quantities, then this file should fully describe the robot in whatever meaningful way to navigation.

I think I've made my position clear. I think separating parameters that belong to packages not robots is confusing, if you don't want one long file of parameters, they should be split up by nodes. For any parameters that are genuinely needed across multiple units, a global parameter server makes sense. All parameters for these packages are effectively robot specific not only relating to the physical characteristics, but the compute power as well. Cherry picking things like kinematic limits as "more robot specific" than the compute platform to support more samples / costmap size / update rates / motion model parameters of noise / laser characteristics seems arbitrary
Take from that what you will...
Closing this PR due to lack of consensus. We may re-approach this topic if and when we address enabling a robot parameter server in the stack
pr_quotes: I'd say if your robot is 2 meters tall and a meter wide, then the size of the costmap is a robot-specific parameter, or if your robot is ackermann vs. differential drive, the Vx/Vy samples might be robot drivetrain specific.

Having 2 different files of parameters for a single program seems like it could be confusing. Someone looks at one file, makes the changes and is none the wiser that others exist. I think for grouping purposes if you're trying to group parameters in not a mega-file, separating parameters by program.
Traditionally configuration files for sp. packages are in different files for more portbility. Ei my AMCL params are in another file than my costmap_2d parameters, from my DWB parameters, etc

In concept I dont mind organizing parameters differently, but if we move some params of [node A] we should probably move all the params of [node A] so that they're all together. Realistically over time I really do mess with all of them, since you don't actually (or at least me) tell DWB it can go as fast as the robot base is capable of since I dont want robots going 5 m/s next to humans
Given their semantic difference, I'd perhaps use two parameters
if we are introducing new planners, controllers, maps, and plugin interfaces to the stack

pr_contents: This is to improve system stability and ease of traceability
Can you give an example of when you might want to disable waiting for TF? I can't think of any - its a critical piece of this package. If you think it makes it unstable, why it is default
and not default

-  Putting the wait for transform in the constructor isn't really necessary, it can be waited for when it is actually used. In this case it waits for it but doesn't use it inside the constructor at all. Thus it is blocking waiting for something it doesn't need yet. Because it is blocked, we have seen that if the constructor never exits, the node time never gets reset by setting the use_sim_time parameter to true, and thus it hangs waiting for the tf forever. It's kind of a deadlock state.

The other option, and I can make this change if it's preferred, is that instead of the 'while' loop where it keeps rechecking for the transform, it could just check once, and if it isn't there, print the warning and move on. I could make that change if its preferred.
My main point wasnt that it shouldn't be included, but that it should not default to
but
because the typical application will want it to be true.
You might be getting into a deadlock state as well because there's no sleep in this while loop so its going to consume a core. That should definitely be changed.

The plugins need TF to be ready to operate. If you don't block until TF is ready and you start processing commands without TF available, that's a safety critical condition that could create a collision.
- if the transform isn't present, it will try the transform later and catch the failure here:

Line 449
      in
So if the transform fails, the robot won't move.
Failing to update the map doesnt stop someone from processing a motion planning request with empty costmaps

You're right, I guess the robot can move, it just won't get the map update. But can't that case still happen anyway? I mean if the transform is working at construction time, then it goes away, or freezes up, you would still hit the case you're talking about.
I'll back that change out of this PR and see if I can get things working without it. If I can't I'll re-submit on another PR later.

Sure, but going down I believe is the users fault, this would be a bad startup procedure. Many robots will power on and when ready immediately process commands, if the constructor blocks it makes sure all the tools have what they need to process. The 2 biggest things I want to see is default

so that unless a user goes out of their way to specify they dont want to wait, it will do the conservative (and in my opinion rational) thing. Second being that you issue a stern warning to users that do pass on waiting and its not up that they could indeed collide due to empty maps.

Steve, I don't mean to argue. I'm just trying to get things working reliably right now. If you haven't had a chance yet to try running the code now would be a great time to start. We're trying to debug issues and there seem to be quite a few due to the lack of message filters and the parameters changes in ROS2. There's no global 'use_sim_time' so every node needs to have the parameter set, and sometimes it doesn't seem to take correctly in the launch file. We're trying to debug these issues now. Anyway, that's another issue I should probably file.
Oh and I backed out the change.

Sorry, As well, just trying to make sure things are safe. To me, that takes total priority over functioning and other considerations. If this navigation framework has little quirks that lets people easily get themselves in trouble, we're going to be having a near impossible time getting any major people (or myself) to move over to it to continue the development and push the community forward (and potentially company ending lawsuits). Simulation should be a first class recipient of support, but all defaults and considerations should be focused on hardware as that's where it counts.

in mainline.
closing since
fixes this in a different way

This adds 2 INFO messages for the /initialpose and /move_base_simple/goal topics for ease of traceability

Adds a 'wait_for_tf' parameter with a default of false to Costmap 2D constructor to bypass waiting for the transform to be there. By making it controlled by a parameter, we make it possible for a user to enable it if they have a use case requiring it

pr_contents: The algorithm must not walk upwards, thus the minimum value must be saved between loops.
(The old method breaks, when start position equals end position)
heads up to
I'm not sure I follow the motivation of the proposed changes.
I fail to see how the algorithm will behave any differently if the start position and the end position are the same, with the addition of the PR.
It is true that the minimum value should continually decrease as the path planning goes on, but I don't think it is necessary to enforce that.
Sorry, for the late reply, I'm currently lacking internet.

I found a  constellation with use_grid_path: true, use_dijkstra: false and start approx end where the loop won't exit The result is a bad alloc exception, when the vector get's too large. That's bad so you need to change something. Unfortunately I'm not familar with the move_base setup. Maybe there are some more parameter which influence this behavior.
The image shows the potential when this happens. Here start is cell (390, 75) and end is (391,73). The path toggles around (390,74) and (389,75) infinitely.
So there might be no minimum at the start position. Thus this is a problem of the potential, not traceback. But it would be nice not to get a bad alloc, when this happens.
To answer your questions
Any of the adjacent cells have a value less than 1e10. Thus the original algorithm always finds a (min_x, min_y) and the condition (min_x == 0 && min_y == 0) will never be hit.
There is at least one case where this results into a bad alloc exception.
With the change, the condition will be hit eventually.
This might happen, when start == end, but also when the potential does have local minimas. In the other cases the algorithm should behave identically.

This alorithm can not walk upwards. If there's a local minimum it would just walk back and forth until the memory is full. Of course it's up to your, how to handle that case. In terms of computing power the fix is really cheap.
I think
fixes the problem with the potential you found,
. Please let me know if that branch works for you.
Also, testing this use case made me shut down my computer twice, so I hope you're happy! :-) That's clearly suboptimal behavior.
I'm glad you found the aktual bug behind this behavior.
woks for me.
Those infinite loops are anoying ;-)
It's not important, but IMO the loop will never hit the condition
if (min_x == 0 && min_y == 0)
return false;
As you added a loop couter, that might not be worth the effort looking into it.
If there's a valid path, yes, it will never hit that condition. I'm not too worried about it though.
Closing this in favor of

return false;

first.

This will make (I hope) the operation of the hand in low power machine much smoother.

pr_contents: Boost > 1.7 has signals by default
Thought I'd look around at this in case it helps decide what to do.
I don't know that the boost 1.7+ justification can be used, as
caters to
and
is
That said, there is precedence for this, and perhaps it's even "proper" to remove
I don't really understand cpp, nor boost nor signals, but hoped to point in a few helpful directions for the maintainers here.
Boost signals (v1) was

Signals (v1) is now removed. Its removal was announced in 1.68 and its deprecation was announced in 1.54. Boost 1.68 is the last release that provides this library. Users are encouraged to use Signals2 instead. The Boost community thanks Douglas Gregor for his work on Signals which served its users well and which also inspired Signals2.
Because of this, the
package fails to build on Boost 1.69+. The fact that this package builds successfully with 1.69+ after this PR is applied shows that it does not actually depend on Boost signals.

pr_contents: This code generates a reference trajectory which minimizes snap.

The class MinimumSnapReferenceTrajectory takes r (order of the derivative, r=4 for snap), tau_vec (a vector of time intervals), and a path (n by 3 matrix) and calculates the optimized polynomial coefficients, P (10*(n-1) by 3 matrix).
Then this P is used to obtain states (ParticleState) and control (Snap) at a given time, by using a member function, atTime(double t).
Output of the unit test can be checked by using
rosrun aerial_autonomy aerial_autonomy-minimum-snap-trajectory-test

Here's a good question
isn't
test a singularity? That would explain the test failure that it should be 0 but is reporting PI. That's the only test failing after fixing some ros2-y things in the interface tests for EKF/UKF.
Hrm, it ought to be, yeah, but I'm curious why it used to work. I once started to go through the process of switching everything to quaternions (
was a fun Jacobian), but it never went anywhere.
In any case, feel free to give the angular y velocity a different value that won't cause it to pass through -pi/2.

Immediately on changing PI/2 to PI/3 we're off to the races. I stared at that for a solid 5 minutes straight before I realized it was the classic singularity condition. It may have worked in ROS1 since its ill-defined, some library change in TF or below TF resulted in changes in the singularity outcome.

(I'm surprised RL doesnt already use quaternions, I'm surprised you couldn't just steal that math from another less-general E/UKF github project. Remind me to not use RL if I start a highspeed drone company)
I fixed up all the tests except the bag tests. For that, I spent a
of time just getting the code to work but I suspect the bag isn't being played. I at least fixed all the parameter issues.
I'm going to un-scope fixing the bag tests and comment them out from the CMakeLists so they dont run on
. If you have cycles / interest for that, please do!
Otherwise, all tests are now working (except 1, working on it now). I'm confident this works as expected from a CI level. Still needs hardware validation.
doesn't work because of the launch files I only migrated the diagnostics launch file to the proper format. But all the non-commented-out tests succeed in launching them
. Migrating the rest will be part of setting up CI. I'm pretty burned out of automated testing for the week... maybe I'll pick that back up in the new year.
Awesome!! Thank you for doing all this!
Alright, passes tests. There's a couple of asterisks I wanted to bring up explicitly.

I had to add a 10% margin to some tests because they were reallly close but not quite on the ball. This is due to the creation of a node in each test so it takes a bit for the network traffic to make connections and I'll typically see about 10% of messages dropped. I think that would account for this change required.
Another thing is the
test
. What I'm seeing is that the actual value of
required to be changed to

to pass. I consistently saw this and even after pulling out a bunch of ROS2 traffic metrics to see if this was a case where also some margin was required, but no. Even when I changed the QoS profiles to promise delivery and give adequate time to process, I'm seeing it hover around 1.8. See math below, but overall I'm seeing both the filters seemingly "lead" the signal which I wouldn't normally expect.

Assuming prefect kinematics, v_f = v_i + a * t. For the first part of this test we apply a 1 m/s2 acceleration over 1 second from stop. That would give us a 1m/s v_f. In reality I see something near 1m/s on occasion but its usually around 1.14m/s. And that's with some dropped messages, which frankly baffles me with constant acceleration being published faster than filter update rate. Either way, the test for the speed:

Passes without an issue, 1, 1.14, all good. Now the next step is where we see the problem. Going back to our kinematics: dx = v_o * t + 0.5 * a * t * t. If we have our initial velocity at 1 m/s and 0 m/s2 acceleration, we should move forward 1m. Knowing dx = (dv/2) * t, we know that the first step's change in pose was 0.5m. So that's 1.5m, in theory. So... why was the test for
? Because a filter lags the signal. Makes sense.

So what we're actually seeing, with those numbers, is 1.14m/s which gives us a displacement in the 0m/s2 acceleration step of 1.14m. Knowing the start and end velocity of the acceleration phase, we get 0.57 as our displacement, totalling to 1.71m displacement. Which is
than what I'm seeing at 1.8m but its in the
error tolerance the test started within.
So that indicates to me that its leading the signal (?) which is odd. So overall for this particular test, I don't really understand where
came from, I think it should be
in a perfect world and the
tolerance band would still cover
from
as the setpoint if we're accurately tracking our signal. I don't know why we're leading the signal, but again if we had set
as our setpoint,
would fall in the tolerance band.
Given that I see this identically in both the EKF and the UKF this gives me a big "phew" feeling that I don't have to look at transfer functions,
. However its consistent.
Ah. This is what I've been waiting a week to see.
This is really great, thanks. I'm slowly working my way through it. In the meantime...

I had to add a 10% margin to some tests because they were reallly close but not quite on the ball. This is due to the creation of a node in each test so it takes a bit for the network traffic to make connections and I'll typically see about 10% of messages dropped. I think that would account for this change required.
Does ROS2 have the ability to wait until all the connections have been established before commencing playback?

The IMU test changes are a little suspicious. Perhaps we'll need to enable debug mode, comment out all the other tests, and run it, and then repeat with the ROS1 versions, just to see what shakes out.
The ridiculous tolerances don't say much for the quality of the tests to begin with. It might make more sense to have a test fixture that inherits from the
and lets us manually fire the callbacks. That would make everything a little more deterministic. But that's outside scope here. I just want to make sure that nothing was broken between ROS1 and ROS2.
Reading over this old code is humbling. There are a lot of things I'd do (very) differently now. :)
Does ROS2 have the ability to wait until all the connections have been established before commencing playback?

I could do something like that, I did a rough test adding sleeps after the node was created to let everything settle down, but it ended up messing up the filter more. That's certainly a "future work" thing to have a single node given to tests vs creating their own, and creating subscribers / publishers / service clients on the fly constantly, that's got to take a toll.

The IMU test changes are a little suspicious. Perhaps we'll need to enable debug mode, comment out all the other tests, and run it, and then repeat with the ROS1 versions, just to see what shakes out.
I'm not, not suspicious of it either, one reason I highlight it.
But that's outside scope here.
Agreed. They pass, they pass, but I also like keeping the server separated for my personal testing style. I like to poke the bear as the bear is seen in the wild.

On the test side of this PR: I'd say there's certainly lots of room for improvement, but the goal here was really to clean up RL functional code, and the changes I made to the tests were singularly with the goal of showing that the functional code changes I made didnt break anything. Test refactoring is out of scope for my attempt of this PR. Though the IMU accelerometer test is showing some confusing results that probably need more investigation. However I'm pretty confident in saying nothing in my refactor caused that so its a feature of the ROS2 port to begin with.
Colcon test now works (except for bags, I know I keep saying I'm not going to do something, then I do it,  but I'm
not going to do the bag file ones, also commented out so it doesnt run default). CI will wait until we're ready to release so we can make use of the ROS PR builder
On my venture debugging I think I can see maybe how the 1.2 -> 1.8 fixes things. See
and
that may potentially be causing a problem. There are 3 places (2 things) that are removed from the code. I don't think they cause this problem since we still query
param on the callback trigger and throw out anything stamped as old, though obviously clearing the queue would be more ideal.
I do notice however that when I run the test by itself, it passes with

. Maybe something is wrong with the resetting, acceleration, or IMU callbacks? If I move it to the first test, it passes but then the second test fails. If I mess with some params there, I can get all the tests to pass. That leads me to believe that the state on
isn't being fully reset.
Also after getting everything running and playing nice, I was able to remove all the 10% margins. So that's no longer something to think about
This is definitely something that should be looked at. I'm not sure I'd block this PR for that however -- I just tested against current
which fails every test so its definitely an improvement. I opened
on this IMUAccel test that we had to change to 1.8m when running after other tests.
any thoughts on this?

Went through everything, looks awesome! I like the new changes and making the ros filter templated! I didn't see anything, had some very minor comments/questions.
My IMU is unfortunately broken :/ so I don't have the ability to test this until I get a new one.
I like the new changes and making the ros filter templated!

This was actually the way it was originally written, but for one reason or another I convinced myself that it wasn't the right approach, so I changed it for ROS2. Happy for the templates to return, though. I'm not that fussed either way.
Is there anything else we want to sort out before we merge this?
I convinced myself that it wasn't the right approach

I think its as good as anything. I think the power of templates is better displayed when there are many, many implementations and needs. Something with 20 implementations the "if/else" on a parameter string gets exhaustive. Pluginlib is good for something like this as well but frankly it didn't come to mind at the time. Templates make it easier to have a bunch of code run and make different executable for each but reduce code redundancy to near-zero. I didn't know it was intentional to remove the templates and create 1 executable for all the filters. I probably wouldn't have done it if I knew that's what you were going for. I thought of R_L in terms of
node and
node, but I suppose I could also get behind a single node with a parameter on each. I haven't gone through the forks recently, has anyone implemented another filter that could be added upstream?
I don't think there's anything I think I need to do before merging. I was hoping for someone independently to give it a whirl and report back, but I think its ready to go.
LGTM. Did not test on-vehicle but the code looks sound.
Thanks for all the effort!

pr_contents: Implements interaction between the Stop Primitive and Grsim
Added motion controller commands for Stop Primitive in grsim_command_primitive_visitor.cpp.
Added stopping at the robots current position and orientation, no option for coasting to a stop yet
Manually tested if the robot stops in Grsim with a simple chron timer in main.cpp:
N/A
I'm having a little trouble thinking of how to add the option to coast to a stop and what that would look like for a MotionControllerCommand
Hmm. This is a tricky problem, because we control the velocity of the robot directly. I'll defer to
with regards to how neccesary modeling coasting to a stop is, but if it's not super important then I think that it's probably more effort then it's worth.
It's worth noting that we're at least on par with the old code though. Just dug around a bit and found the equivalent snippet from the old codebase:
LOL the old code was janky.
The exact behavior of coasting during Stop is really not a big concern, especially in grsim. There's not really cases where we
want to pick coasting vs not coasting in most realistic scenarios I can think of. Right now I think it's more effort than it's worth, so just giving the same behavior regardless of the
boolean is totally fine, just leave a comment in the
function explaining that is intentional.
I added the comment, but is there a way in high level to stop providing power to the robots wheels?
No, our High Level / Gameplay logic doesn't control wheel power directly. That's why we abstract things with the Primitives.

There's no way to stop providing power to the robot wheels in grSim because we are only able to directly control the robot's velocity. There's no concept of "wheel power" like how you would expect in real life.
I believe our real robots do simply stop providing power to the wheels when coasting to a stop in real life, but we unfortunately can't perfectly replicate that with grSim.

pr_contents: if we put this code into jsk_common, we'd better to support same system for other robots,
could you check if this works on staro and if not please create script to match this program.
could you check if this works on staro and if not please create script to match this program.
I think this script works when
has a state named
. But for now STARO and HRP2JSKNTS do not have a such state, and I got the following two ideas.
The first one looks better, but battery infromation has no relationship with hrpsys...
Do you have any suggestions?
in hrpsys. battery status is published already in some topic?
Currently, not.
However, before implement it into hrpsys-base, we need to discuss
which information should be used as battery status.
On pr2, what does battery status include?
a lot
I think we do not need to fill all the fields of the BatteryServer.
PR2のバッテリーの仕組みがわかってきた気がしますが，
hrpsysがバッテリー情報をpublishする部分はどうするのが正しいのでしょうか？
「hrpsysを挟む」ことを考えずに，/battery/serverのtopicを出すだけのPRは作れそうですが，こちらを作ってよいでしょうか？
（jsk-ros-pkg/jsk_batteryを作る or jsk_toolsに色々加える）
今回導入しようとしているバッテリーはPR2のocean server社のバッテリーのようにAPIが存在するわけではないので，その代わりにarduinoを使ってrosserialでバッテリー情報を通信しようとなっています．
「hrpsysを挟む」ことを考えると，もしかしてバッテリー情報を一番最初に出力する部分がrosに依存しているのは良くない（rosserialを使うのは良くない）のでしょうか？
hrpsysってバッテリ情報とれるAPI用意してないんだっけ?
にそれっぽいのがないのでないと思っていて，作るのかなと思っています．
iobにはread_powerという関数があるようです.
あるならそこのインターフェイスを実装するのが正解じゃない?
◉  ryohei
On Wed, Jan 7, 2015 at 3:57 PM, orikuma
wrote:
iobにはread_powerという関数があるようです.
Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
hrpsysを通す必要があるかな？
HRP2は、体内側のバッテリコネクタに１本電圧よむせんがあって、
IFボードを介してc側で読み込むことができます。
read_digital_output的な箇所でよめます。
一方、HRP2新バッテリではそれが使えません。
HRP2新バッテリでは、何かのデバイス（今ためしてるのはセンサ＋arduino）でバッテリから読み込むので、それがｃ側につながってる必要、縛りはとくにないです。
HRP2新バッテリ、STARO系ではどちらにつなげてもいいですが、個人的には
cでない側のPCに差して、hrpsys-baseを介さない方がPR2とも合わせやすいしシンプルに思いますが、いかがでしょうか。
あとhrpsys-baseだと、read_powerかread_digital_outputみたいなのでよみますが、
いずれにしても電圧が12V系、80V系などあったときにきれいにいかなさそう。
皆さん
アドバイスありがとうございます．
では，jsk_battery的なPRを作って送ってみます．
もし，hrpsysを通す必要が出てくるのであれば，
read_power： 電流と電圧
read_digital_output：バッテリー残量
を取得するように書くとして，その中ではrosserialを使わずにarduinoとの通信を書く感じになるのでしょうか．
だけど，コントローラで状況をしりたいということはない？
バッテリの制御基板は産総研も考えているらしいので，金広さんに連絡していいものを共同で作るのがいいと思います．
◉ Kei Okada
On Wed, Jan 7, 2015 at 6:27 PM, Shunichi Nozawa
wrote:
あとhrpsys-baseだと、read_powerかread_digital_outputみたいなのでよみますが、
いずれにしても電圧が12V系、80V系などあったときにきれいにいかなさそう。
Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
バッテリの制御基板は産総研も考えているらしいので，金広さんに連絡していいものを共同で作るのがいいと思います．
そうですね、こちら伺っているので、長期的にはこちらにしてきたいと思います。
だけど，コントローラで状況をしりたいということはない？
ちなみに今のところこれが必要と思ったことがないのですが、どういう状況がございますでしょうか。
電源に関する何かしらのプログラムがｃでもｖでもどちらでもOKとすると、
いろいろ依存関係やOSのバージョンなど考慮して、ｃよりｖの方が管理がラクなように思います。
僕のイメージだと，基盤があって，それが現在の電圧，電流，残り時間を出してくれて，readするだけでよくて，それがioボード経由か
シリアル／USB経由かはわからないけど，そういう状況にているので，電源に関するプログラム，というのは存在しなくて，readするだけ．
hrpsysのエマージェンシーは議論が続いている気がするけど，電源低下もその一種なのでこれが起こればemergencyとして，
サーボオフするなり，warningだすなりする機能が考えられる．エンコーダのトビがあったら止まる，とか，バランスを崩していたら止まる，
とか，足裏が擦れていたら止まるとか，そういうのは最下層のプログラムで行われるべき事柄．コリジョンチェックも最下層で行われている．
そのデータはros経由でパブリッシュされてなんか見ることはできるだろうし，そのパブリッシュされた結果をみて中するプログラムもあるだろうけど，それは色々可能性がある．
最下層のプログラムは，落ちたら終わりなので，かなり丁寧に作ってデバッグも最優先．
それ以外の上のプログラムはまぁ落ちてもよいかというレベル．
電源は最下層部分だろうから（とはいえ電源がないときに何ができるかは，ないかもしれないけど），それは最下層の部分に入れておくべき．
現状のシステムで最下層はhrpsys本体．ROSの通信がつながらない，外部のPCのホスト名が引けない，いろいろあったとしても，体内のCは
動き続けていることが期待される．
電源は論理的に最下層だけど，実装として最下層部分とは違うシステムで動いているのは，再優先で作って置かなければいけない最下層部分を
広げることになって手間が増えるだけなので破綻する．
とはいえarduinoのボードで作っていて自分で通信をちゃんと書ける人はそんなにいないだろうから，rosserialでつくってjsk_common/jsk_arduion_apps
みたいにあたして，温度管理のarduino基盤のプログラムと共に置いておくのでいいともいますが，
新しい電源管理ボードは長期的と言っても１ヶ月もないと思います．
◉ Kei Okada

pr_title: Use public virtual for Controller inheritance.
pr_contents: I can put up some tests around this if it's otherwise a welcome change, but I wanted to put forward the suggestion for discussion prior to getting deeper into it. The proposed modification allows controllers to be extended via multiple inheritance. In particular, this is relevant where a new hardware interface type is being added as part of the extension, since that requires inheriting from a differently-templated version of
than what might have been in the original controller's hierarchy.
Consider the following diagram:
In this scenario,
contains virtual methods which are a hook for an extending controller to be able to hitch on additional functionality. We already do this today with DiffDriveController—

, and there are (internal) controllers which use that hook to supply additional wheel-level speed constraints to the controller in real time. For example, based on higher-level knowledge such as position in the map or satisfying other system constraints.
The new capability that I would like is to be able to add
in
, and to be able to do so while maintaining the is-a relationship of inheritance, rather than having to fake it by having the "original" controller as a member and using pass-through methods (
Based on my testing, making this change proposed here allows the multiple inheritance to succeed, at the cost of two additional pointers in each controller's vtable.
Further reading:
Good old C++ and that diamond problem...
On my side, I welcome the idea. This is something we discussed a few times with
and
a few years back. Tests would be very welcome :)
Also LGTM.
Other than the additional pointers in each controller's vtable, is there any other drawback?
And how would those additional pointers impact performance?
It'd only be a slight performance drop of having to make a jump to resolve to the right function implementation.
This is a dry description of the thing:
But I quite like the drawing here:
(although it's of virtual functions, it works the same way for class-level virtual inheritance)
My questions are related with the overhead introduced, as commented here:
Likely a small penalty, but that actually depends on how many times the virtual methods are being called.
I simply want to make clear we all agree that penalty is neglectable and won't impact significantly existing code. I've already approved it because I think it's neglectable.
I personally don't know offhand which methods will be called heavily, but I think at least the
mehod in
will:
, and it'll pay the penalty of the two pointers, right? (

Okay, there's now a test and trivial demonstration controller here to show what this looks like. I think the main thing is figuring out from a design/architectural point of view if this is a worthwhile thing to try to support, or if it really would be better to insist on doing extension by composition.
Here's an example of achieving the same effect via composition (dropping these files into the PR changes allows the new tests to still pass):
Pluses: IMO easier to reason about (it's a controller delegating part of its operation to a sub-controller), template shenanigans are minimized, no change required to core ros_control packages.

Minuses: A non-toy implementation would have to pass through a bunch more methods (starting, stopping, state_), and requiring the other class to provide the helper method override is awkward and friend-sharing data back and forth across that boundary could get messy.
Thoughts?
Thoughts on this, reviewers?
I'm generally positive about this PR
I've just discovered that our
page got rolled back for some reason...

Could you please put together a short tutorial for the wiki? Feel free to use the test code as an example or other. I'll migrate the tutorials over from github again but I'll make sure to have a backup of yours there as well.
Please put together a short tutorial here on this thread. The test code or something simpler with a bit of explanation will do. I'll place it on the
wiki and the ROS wiki as well.
Once we have that I'll merge ;)

Sounds good— sorry for the delay. There's a bit of a chicken and egg here, where the standard upstream ros_controllers are not really set up for being extended, much less multiple-extended. Which is fine, it just means any discussion/tutorials about this capability is a little bit abstract until the whole thing is better and more widely understood.
Either way, I can definitely write up something based on the extensible controllers tests which are part of this PR.
Okay, here's a first draft to kick the tires on:
As regular shared object files, each library of controllers is free to link whatever
external helper libraries it requires to do its job. However, there are two special cases
of modularizing controllers, which are discussed here.
If a controller exposes one or more virtual methods, then it is possible for an extending
controller to subclass that base controller, and override the virtual methods, providing
additional capabilities or constraints.
An example of this could be a generic mobile base controller (such as
which is focused on accomplishing three basic tasks:
In some cases, additional constraints (such as a "slow zone") may be possible to implement
within the local planner, or by placing a node in between
and the
node. However, there are some scenarios where correctly applying them requires knowledge
both of the kinematic intent (the Twist message) but also of the individual wheel speeds.
An example of this is where a low-level system such as a safety-rated laser scanner is
observing the wheels and will trip an e-stop if either wheel exceeds the safe threshold.
In this case, an attractive option is to define a subclass controller of the generic mobile
base controller, which can override a
or similar method. This way, the
functionality of the base controller may be reused without needing to refactor it into
a common library.
For more complicated scenarios, it may be desirable to create a controller which is the
composite of multiple smaller controllers, but uses overridden virtual methods to allow
some element of co-operation between the lower level controllers, as defined by methods
in the composite.
Examples might include:
A difficulty arises when attempting this because of the C++ diamond problem, since both
controllers being extended will ultimately have ControllerBase as a base class:
The ros_control framework resolves the diamond by declaring the base classes in the controller
chain as
, but because of the diamond,
methods which are virtual in
ControllerBase must be overridden in FooBarController, even if the only implementation is to call
the individual implementations in FooController and BarController. In particular, if MultiInterfaceController
is used for either or both of the controllers being extended, it will be necessary to override
the
method and supply an implementation which either calls your init method,
or calls those supplied by the source controllers, in the preferred order.
As the multiple inheritance pattern for controllers becomes more known and used, it may
be possible to offer a template class for this use case, which would provide default
implementations of the standard functions, avoiding some of the boilerplate.
I'd like a temperature check on PR
. If we can commit to merging that for Melodic, then the above proposed tutorial content should be reworked to use it.

because it breaks both C++ and ROS APIs (see

subclass allowing for more than one HW interface, i.e., a multi-interface analog of
. Since that is an API addition, it can be iterated on with more time and incorporated later in the jade cycle.

, thanks for the review. I've addressed your points, which show up as two changesets containing 'Sachin Chitta code review' in the summary. I'll squash them with their parent before merging.

What will not be in the scope of this work package is a ControllerBase subclass allowing for more than one HW interface, i.e., a multi-interface analog of Controller. Since that is an API addition, it can be iterated on with more time and incorporated later in the jade cycle.
I went against this statement and implemented a proposal for a
. I felt that a decent reference implementation would allow to make design shortcomings evident. So far so good :-). If you want to browse the proposed API, please look at the
class. One nifty power-user feature is that
, so you can write a controller that for instance requires two interfaces, one of which is optional, and its absence won't prevent the controller from initializing and starting.
I also took the opportunity in
to
this new class, and to test the
more thoroughly, in general.

was affected. I'm now tackling

This update is highly recommended. This fixes some of the issues we have with the hand.
The current hand controller follows a very old firmware script. The updates are listed below:
Who know how script works ?
Definition of the script (and source code) is required to evaluate this PR.
BTW, sending angles is required for a hand which has more than one joint (joint not controlled by scripts)
The script is the default firmware script.
I am assuming that the currently deployed firmwares all have the same script installed.
However, since we are sometimes having issues between firmware version and ROS controller version, I highly recommend that
and that there is a way to check the firmware version from ROS side to give warnings when the versions do not match.

Regarding the send angles, are you talking about the sending angles before the grasp and ungrasp command? The feature itself should still be there but yes, I did remove them from these particular functions.
Could you please investigate whether we really need to send angles before the grasp and ungrasp with the seed_hand? Thanks.
Now when you bringup the controller, it will print the driver version. example: "Version of driver is [1.0.80.0.0]".
Assuming that
, this pull request should work with driver version 1.0.80.0.0. Please report if you have a different version. (this only checks the upper controller)
I confirmed driver version 1.0.80.0.0 when bring up the controller.
I've tried some pick and place task to test hand run well or not.
In the present, hand run very well. I've never seen hand failure like

Is it okay to merge this pull request? It has been checked that the code works with both type of hands and is actually more stable as well (the script on the firmware side has changed at 10/7/2017 but the ros side of code has not been updated since this change. this pull request does the update for the ros side). Thanks.
pr_details_more: remove sending angles in grasp. reason: not required. current grasp finishes in 2.8 seconds.
remove sending angles in ungrasp. reason: not required. moreover, this could cause step-out.
remove time setups for grasp, ungrasp. reason: not used due to above changes.
set electrical current down in grasp to power. reason: current down to 30 is not enough for grasping.
remove setting electrical current in ungrasp. reason: not required.
add servo_on at end of grasp_angle. reason: to cancel loud noises when there is a step-out.

pr_title: Sanitize node memory consumption with a smaller TF buffer size.
pr_contents: Fixes an (almost) unbounded growth of the TF buffer.
See the heap profile logs in the PR for more information.
Noticed this with a profiling session with the
heap profiler.
Tested with the localization demo of
, see the README there.
Added this to the launch XML of the cartographer node in
Because of the slow-down by valgrind, rviz and bagplay were removed from the launch file. Once the node was initialized I used
for slow data playback.
The
logs are attached, I recommend to open them with the
which you can get via
With the previous buffer limit (
), the queue size grows steadily to a peak of more than 25MiB for this dataset. It stays more or less constant at 2MiB with a cache time of
This is likely a cause for memory issues as reported e.g.
Do you know why this was set to such a high value in the first place?
I remember stumbling into this as well! Tried running git blame and following the source... it seems this comes from the oldest commit, the initial import of the Cartographer codebase.
Yes, looks like a constant that was added very early and never questioned again ;)
Please also update node_grpc_main.cc (and check elsewhere).
Good catch!
is included. Reverted to a constant of 10 seconds for the buffer time instead of a parameter, which seems reasonably long enough for me. Unless someone complains: ready for merge.
do you see any issues having the default TF buffer length (10s)?

seems fine to me. I do not remember why we set the constant so high, probably because we did the TF lookups later in the pipeline at which point we could have fallen arbitrarily behind. Not sure if that was the case though.
merge
Merge requested by authorized user gaschler. Merge queue now has a length of 1.

pr_contents: Fix the illegal gpu memory access error in ndt_mapping gpu, which causes ndt_mapping crash as reported in
List related PRs against other branches:
The error still happens on my PC.
Ubuntu 14.04 + ROS Indigo
GeForce GTX TITAN Black
CUDA 8.0
Can you check the operation on Ubuntu 16.04?
I tested on Ubuntu 16.04.
it work longer than before,
but when I made a map for 200 sec, the program ended with out of memory.
I did it with the same rosbag (moriyama/20150324.bag).
This program still falls on the way, but it is much faster than PCL's original.
Good Job!
your error is different from the one reported in

, which relates to illegal memory access on the GPU memory. I guess the reason of your error is the kernel at line 780 of the NormalDistributionsTransform.cu requires too many registers per block for launching. Actually I 've never had that error on my pc before, but I'm gonna fix it soon.
can you tell me how many points are there on the loaded map when the program failed?
The last message of ndt_mapping is as below :
So, 19837423 points.
I see. So your GPU cannot handle around 20 million points.

I am working on a solution for that out of memory problem. By dividing the input point cloud into smaller chunks (around 2 millions points per each) and process them one by one, the out of memory problem can be avoided. However, I am not sure about the accuracy of this implementation method. Though when I ran it on my pc, the output map looks the same as when using CPU, I still need more tests.
Sounds good. I am looking forward to your improvement.
Great!  i will test later
yes. mapping takes too much memory, and can we use 'generator' and write data to tmp files on disk to save memory?

actually another function called approximate ndt mapping has already solved that problem. It loads a portion of the current map to the main memory instead of all the map. So it consumes less memory than this ndt mapping.
，hi, dear, yes, I test now.  quite faster than NDT_mapping, but still have many problems .
example:
I think it needs to spend time and spirit to optimize.
and much warning info in the command window. this warning is same as ndt_mapping.

during handling process, the map data will lost suddenly and disappear, and re-produce the map from scratch. this step I tried many times, and almost in every loop will lost data, I think it's easy to re-produce the issue.
approximate_ndt_mapping node outputs PCDs in /home/.ros/ directory every certain distance. So the data is not lost.
, hi, dear, yes, I checked the directory, and find the files.
Thanks!
so the disappearance is normal case, right? is it cleaning and releasing the old memory?
The disappearance is normal. It is releasing the old memory.

pr_title: Start relative poses at target frame
pr_contents: Disclaimer: This is a late-night development to get one specific use case to work. I'd appreciate a review and comment on whether this makes sense for the project at large :)
The description in
describes the change in some detail - basically, with this change, setting a pose input "relative" should result in the initial
tf being the identity, rather than
Thanks for the PR! I'll look this over tonight. I think you're probably correct on this. Thanks again!

Looking at this a little deeper, I think we may be looking at another case where IMU data has to be handled differently. For example, imagine a robot that drives sideways on the wall. Its world coordinate frame is rotated by 90 degrees from the ground plane. Let's say we are running an instance of ekf_localization_node on some device in the ground plane, and we wanted to know the position of the wall robot w.r.t. the ground plane. If we turn on relative mode, we take the wall vehicle's world frame X-Y position (and remember that since it started sideways, its X-Y plane is the wall itself), and "removes" its initial X-Y position. This leaves it in some position in the X-Y frame.

we need to transform that position so that it's in the X-Z frame, so we apply the target frame transformation. In other words, the order of operations was (1) compute the difference, and (2) apply the transform.

I think part of the issue you're having is that IMUs always report their orientations w.r.t. the world frame. In our wall robot example, it will start out with a roll of 90, and then after moving around a bit, it will still have a roll of 90. When we take the difference, we get 0 (correct), but then if we apply the transform to the ground plane device running the EKF, it adds 90 again.

If the IMU were to always report its orientation data w.r.t. its world frame when the robot started, the method I have would work: if the robot on the wall turned so it was driving straight up the wall, its world frame

should be 90. In that case, the transformation scheme I'm using would work: first we remove the initial measurement, yielding some yaw value, and then we apply the transformation, so that yaw for the wall vehicle is pitch for the device in the ground plane. Unfortunately, IMUs don't work this way.
One other thing: you're applying the transform in the wrong direction. You're multiplying the pose times the target frame as the initial measurement, so what you get is this:
First time we get a measurement (line 2090 in your version):
Then, for some future measurement at time N (line 2094 in the your version):
Finally, we apply the target frame transformation again (lines 2270-2284 in your version, but only because we're using IMU data):

In the end, all you're doing is removing the target frame transformation entirely. While this gives the correct result for what you want, there's a better way. The real issue here - and I concede there is a bug - is that for relative mode measurements of IMU data, we
want to apply the orientation correction for the IMU. If your IMU is rolled over and we always "remove" that initial orientation, then we have no need to carry out the transform.
Try this: before line 2248 in your version, you need to insert this:
Try inserting that and then undoing your changes. Let me know how it goes!
First off, thanks for taking the time to type this up! I'm not 100%  sure I got everything you talked about, but I think I did for the major points.
You're obviously right about me removing
entirely. It was late and I didn't notice, sorry.
I haven't tried out your suggestion yet, but I will, as soon as possible.
However, I'm not sure that simply omitting
for relative measurements is correct, either, if we're taking into account the entire IMU pose, rather than just its orientation;
Consider a long robot with
at the front and the IMU mounted way at the back.
If we lift that back end, but leave the front at the same height, the IMU will report its pitch changing accordingly, but
its z coordinate increasing.
But since we're interested in the movement of
, that ist not what we want.
Instead, I think we need to do something like the following (caveat: it is late again and I'm not sure if the order is correct this time...):
Does that make sense?

IMUs don't report position, only orientation (so no Z). They report linear acceleration, which is handled in a different callback function. Also, sensors that provide Z position (i.e., that are not IMUs) are handled differently in the pose callback function.

However, this does raise an interesting point, which is unrelated to the relative parameter: let's say we have a depth sensor on the rear end of a UUV. The depth sensor is measuring data in the world frame (
or
). Right now, the
function attempts to transform pose data from the reported message
to the
(or whatever your
parameter is set to) frame. So for our depth sensor, you would need to define a transform from
to the
that technically has the transform from
in it.  This is wrong, as it won't handle the vehicle's orientation. What we really want to do is this:

So, for example, if we have a depth sensor that has a X offset of -1.5 meters from the vehicle center, and a +Z offset of 0.5 meters, then when the vehicle is level, then (assuming our depth sensor reads negative values as it gets deeper, so -Z is down), we just subtract the Z offset from the raw measurement to get the vehicle center measurement. However, if the vehicle is pitched down, then the "true" vertical offset in the
frame is a function of both the X offset
the Z offset. Therefore, we need a combination of the
transform and the vehicle's current orientation, which is specified by part of the
transform.
Oh. Sorry, I got a bit lost in
there and didn't notice translation is handled elsewhere.
I'm not sure I follow your other point. There should be a transform from
to
-- possibly published by one of the
nodes, and including the vehicle's orientation -- and one from
to
, most likely as part of the vehicle's URDF. Why wouldn't that TF tree handle orientation?
For this reason (and I've run into this before):
Let's say we simply use the
method and go from the
to
. What really happens is that the measurement gets transformed as
We first apply the
to

transformation. Let's say that the sensor has an offset of (-1, 0, 0.5) from the vehicle center, and for now, we'll ignore the orientation of the sensor w.r.t. the body frame, as it doesn't matter (a depth sensor rotated on its side reads the same depth). We get a depth measurement from the sensor of 10 meters. Now we apply the
transform, and we get a depth of 10.5 meters. Now, let's say our vehicle is at pose (0, 0, 10), with RPY of (0, 0.4, 0). This is the same as the

(technically its inverse, but that doesn't matter). We apply that transform and we get (0, 0, 10.5) rotated by an RPY of (0, 0, 0.4), and then we add (0, 0, 10) to it, yielding something like (just making this up) (2.3, 0, 19.2).
What we lose in this transform chain is the fact that we only want to rotate the linear
of the sensor from the vehicle origin, i.e.,
, but just the 0.5 meters, which we

add to 10. Imagine that the vehicle is pitched down 90 degrees. The offset from the sensor to the vehicle centroid is 1 meter (the X offset). Now imagine it's level. The offset from the vehicle centroid is 0.5 meters. In both of these cases, you want to rotate that linear offset (
) by
the vehicle's current orientation (
the orientation of the
transform).
It should be pretty straightforward to write a few lines of code with
that go through these steps.
I see. So the depth sensor always measures distance straight down?
We've encountered a similar situation, and yeah, the TF tree isn't perfectly suited to setups like that. We ended up using a virtual link to 'undo' the rotation of
, so the measurement frame is always level with the ground.
For sensors that measure in a straight line from their reference frames (say, a Kinect or laser scanner), this wouldn't be an issue, would it?

If a sensor is measuring a range to some landmark, then any node that consumes that information should be able to use that information directly. If a sensor is using a Kinect to determine its 3D pose, then  I think this could be an issue. I'm not seeing many responses to my ROS Driver Sig post on this topic, so I'm tempted for now to push any such logic to the driver and just carry out the transforms as I am.
In any case, can you verify if the code change (reverting your changes and adding my lines) worked? Thanks!

Worked on this a lot over the weekend. Long story short: I know how to fix this, but it isn't with the code change I gave you here. I just pushed a release, but they haven't been synched yet, so I'll try to fix this and release it ASAP.
Thanks for continuing to look into this!
I'm afraid I haven't found the time to test your suggestion yet, sorry.

I think I've addressed this issue in the latest release. It's out for Indigo, and Jade/Hydro will follow whenever the next package sync happens. Let me know if you have any issues when you've updated.
Just to formally wrap this up: The new release works as expected. Thanks!

pr_title: Do not republish unchanged scan matched point clouds.
pr_contents: Before, republishing the point clouds at high frequency caused unnecessary
computational load.
This also fixes an issue seen in RViz:
After replaying a bag, point clouds with the same timestamp were continued to
be published. These were never dropped by the PointCloud2 display leading to
excessive memory consumption and bad visualization performance.

pr_title: support map loading in offline node
pr_contents: Not sure whether this makes sense. The offline node consumes data as quickly as possible which means it might fall behind easily and does not produce meaningful output. I think the offline node is really only useful for producing a map as quickly as possible. Opinions?

I'm considering the case of merging a new rosbag into an existing serialized data. Assume that the new rosbag discovers a new area that hasn't been visited before. Then, you just want to add a new information into the existing data instead of replaying all rosbags again.
Or do you have a plan to provide a way of merging two serialized data into one?
This is my use case too, I would also like to be able load prior mapping knowledge into the offline node.
That makes sense to me. Let's get this in then.

Note that right now going this route will not be as good as doing multi trajectory. The reason is that the serialized state does not contain the associated scans for each submap (and no IMU and odometry data of course) - which means that loop closure can only be done from new scans to old maps, not the other way around. And of course the loaded map is frozen in the optimization problem - which could be configurable as well.
Great! Although, isn't loop closure currently done only between new scans and finished submaps?
Then maybe add a
that
should be replaced by some better deserialization of full SLAM state as non-frozen trajectories once possible? And change the parameter name to reflect the intention?
I added
to replace
and renamed
to
. If you have any better suggestion for naming filename, let me know.
you don't necessarily have to claim the TODO :) The person inside the parentheses is the assigned person, who may not be the same person as the TODO author.

pr_title: Add finalize option in write state service.
pr_contents: to support saving of fully optimized state without killing the cartographer node.
Reopen of

Thanks. Can you explain how you want to use this? Should I imagine that you have a robot running SLAM, then you want to save the optimized state to disk. Now your cartographer_node is not consuming sensor data anymore as all trajectories have been finished. What do you do now with that cartographer_node? Do you want to start a new trajectory now and localize against the existing ones?

Yes, I can start a new trajectory to localize the robot or to extend the existing map without killing the robot. Since our robots should be operatable 24/7, I need to achieve the followings without killing the cartographer_node.

Also, I had a trouble to find a moment to save the pose graph after SLAM programmatically when optimization takes longer than robot's actual movement. As a cartographer developer, I can more or less tell when to save the map by checking terminal logs(
). But, I cannot ask the robot operators to read terminal logs to find out when to save the map. Thus, I would like to guarantee that the generated pbstream file is fully optimized by adding
option in write_asset service. So that, I can tell robot operators that they can just call this service to generate optmized map.
Ok, makes sense to me. I am just wondering whether conflating state writing and finishing and running optimization is the right thing. Currently WriteState is a "const" functions so to speak. Setting
then modifies the state.

We already have a call to finish a trajectory. I am wondering whether it wouldn't be possible to add a ROS method that forces an optimization and returns when the optimization is done. This way you could
This way other people might be more easily able to reuse these building blocks in a different way for their own use case. WDYT?
Sounds good to me. Basically,
is a missing step for my usecase.
Then, how about creating a ros service that finishes all trajectories and call
? so I can call
afterward. I think issuing
via ros service call would make headaches in cartographer level
Yes I was also wondering about how difficult it is to make such a
call. I will take a look tomorrow and get back to you. Otherwise a new call that does finish all trajectories and optimizes sounds good to me.
Ok. Let me know how your investigation goes.
FYI,
was being evil when I was trying to refactor
as we discussed in
I agree about adding a
service.
Regarding the work queue, I think that

(the method in the pose graph) should be pushed to the work queue as well. I have refactored that in my manual constraints branch, but merging that branch is currently postponed. I am very busy atm, but I was planning on singling out some smaller changes I made there as separate PRs. Refactoring
is one of these changes. With that change, it plays well with that check!
Small update: I spent some time today studying the concurrency in PoseGraph / ConstraintBuilder but I need to think about this a little more before I understand it fully.
To separate the issues from
from this discussion here, could upload a PR where you show how you tried to refactor
and ran into the
check in
I looked at your custom constraints PR. Why do you think refactoring
in this way is advantageous?
One thing I guess is that the trimmers are not invoked as part of the current
It's really been a while since I wrote that code so I don't remember right now, but my guess would be the following: I have multiple things (such as
) which can trigger optimization (no longer just
as it's now called), so I refactored that into
didn't play well with that (e.g. if
is called a little bit before, or during the final optimization).
I still have a really tight schedule, but I will get back to this when I can :)
