pr_contents: I separated the source code cleanup of
from
to allow for early merging of the latter and thus fixing the ROS build farm.
Please argue why do you think that this cleanup is not more readable.
I think, reducing the number of
checks improves readability.
You seem to complain only about the struct, don't you?
This struct is overly-complicated and takes much longer to understand than two simple bools in the original approach.
I think the struct is simple, but you are right, I'm combining declaring, instantiating, and initializing the struct.
I think this is usual practice in C++ programming and the most efficient way to initialize.
Do you prefer to split these three steps?
you bundle declaring the struct, creating an array of structs, and initializing them unnecessarily, which takes a long time to parse
I guess you refer to human "parsing". The compiler probably doesn't care.
you mix in conditional logic with the initializer
Yes, why not? First computing the bool and then assigning to the struct would require copying - which you complained about for the other variables.
there is an unnecessary copy of threshold values
I create this struct (and need to copy the threshold values, yes) because I want to index into the struct array and access both independent variables in a
fashion. For me, it's much easier to "parse" the struct array definition than the nested and repeated
conditions of the previous code. But maybe that's a matter of taste.
Can you declare the struct then initialize it in two separate statements / lines? I think this would be enough to be more human readable.
Done your requested changes and rebased due to conflicts.
Travis reports build errors though:

I strongly believe that these changes shouldn't be merged. This takes really simple code and adds data types, a switch statement, and control flow that simply does not need to be there. Code should be simple not complex.

I think that code should be easily readable as well as efficient. The set of lengthy boolean expressions in the previous code were much harder to comprehend than the simple switch case statements here. I agree that my code is longer, but in my opinion it is easier to read.
In my humble opinion this whole request is bikeshedding.
If Robert insists on it (which he did), then it was ok to merge.
There was one approval already.

Please refrain from calling bikeshedding to dismiss opposing opinions when you get bored of them. It only makes people want to flip the table on you instead of encouraging healthy discussions. We don't always have to agree, it is enough to see the motivation of others.

Also, please have my unsolicited opinion along with some gummy bears: The struct is indeed unnecessary abstraction here. Yes, many things can and are being used in C++ in extremely complex ways and they compile and work but they are conceptually wrong because they overcomplicate what wasn't complex.
We can talk a lot about readability while the codebase is full of
statements. I'd rather break my code into smaller functions or have long nested if-s if that's what it takes to avoid
-derivatives.
Please refrain from calling bikeshedding to dismiss opposing opinions when you get bored of them.
That was not my intention and I hope
did not understand it that way.
I called bikeshedding on the whole request and personally I agree with
and your statements.
But given support from two maintainers it was ok to merge the request.
And discussing a request to change it back without functional changes or wider scope is not any better from my perspective..
Thanks for the sweets.
I think we're on the same page here :)
To clarify my PR approval - it was a compromise where
separated out the creation of the struct from its initialization, which was a step towards the readability
argues. Overall I wanted to move on with this new feature so approved it.

pr_title: New isValidVelocityMove() for checking time between two waypoints given velocity
pr_contents: This is a more computationally efficient version of the previously used isValidVelocityMove() functions added in
This allows faster Descartes-type functionality
Side note,
: Is this moveit-integrated version of Descartes something you plan on making open source or something you're going to keep internal to your company?
In either case, is there a reason you've decided to clone the Descartes work rather than work with us to make it better or fit your needs?
my Descartes-MoveIt work is

from my thesis last year, which was funded by NIST and a collaboration with you guys at SwRI. This patch was created then and I'm trying to get back to the mainstream MoveIt!. Let's have a phone call to discuss collaborations on this effort.
ping
can I get a review? I already have one +1
I think the old function
should call into these new functions. Currently the old function, doesn't protect against non-standard joints.

I think the old function RobotState::isValidVelocityMove(const RobotState& other, const JointModelGroup* group, double dt) const should call into these new functions. Currently the old function, doesn't protect against non-standard joints.

I disagree - the RobotState version supports arbitrary groups of joints that are not necessary inline, whereas these new ones are optimized for the most common use case of a simple kinematic chain where the vector is in order. This can't be easily configured to call into each other without a big performance hit.

pr_title: [runtime issue] remove render_shapes for attached objects when the RobotStateDispla gets disabled
pr_contents: this fixes a crash on the first update after reenabling the plugin:
OGRE EXCEPTION(5:ItemIdentityException): SceneNode 'rviz' not found. in SceneManager::getSceneNode at /build/ogre-1.9-mqY1wq/ogre-1.9-1.9.0+dfsg1/OgreMain/src/OgreSceneManager.cpp (line 920)

You can trigger the crash in rviz (or any other application loading the RobotState or PlanningScene rviz plugin) by attaching an object and then toggling the "enable" checkbox. It will crash on the first RobotState update after reenabling when it calls render_shapes_.clear(). Apparently some more nodes get deleted/removed once the plugin is disabled and it subsequently does not find them.
Please note that
At first glance, I'm unsure about this request.
Does this require that each received
contains all attached objects (i.e.
I want to get rid of
eventually, so we might publish diff RobotState messages in the future.
Well, this handles the case were you disable the whole plugin (the main checkbox). This will also stop the planning scene monitor and generally not receive updates.
If you don't touch the main checkbox however (do not disable the plugin), this won't have any effects and being more efficient wrt

is still possible. I think for planning scenes there is some mechanism to request a "full update", maybe something similar is needed for the robot state/attached objects? or is this included in the planning scene update?
Well, this handles the case were you disable the whole plugin (the main checkbox). This will also stop the planning scene monitor and generally not receive updates.
fair enough.
or is this included in the planning scene update?
yes it is.
Well, this handles the case were you disable the whole plugin (the main checkbox).
This is true for the
and the
, but the start/goal state visualization in the
trigger this function too.
I'm not sure this affects them though.
Still, it feels weird to remove additional rendering shapes just because the main object is set to invisible...
Ah, we don't use these. Toggling these does not seem to be affect by the crash in the first place.  After applying the patch they still show the attached object (after the first update ...)

My (limited) understanding is that there is a hierarchy of SceneNodes, the attached objects being some leaf of that tree(/forest?). Now disabling the plugin ("visible_" = false) will remove some node called "rviz". This leads to the attached objects SceneNodes dangling around somewhere and subsequently an exception once they get deleted during the next update. Catching (and ignoring) that exception leads to crashes elsewhere and is not really a solution anyway as then the render shapes will still be around.
Now I feel like I stared into the Abyss for too long, but I believe I managed to track down the underlying issue. Please have a look at
for a (hopefully better) fix.
your version works as well and looks cleaner, will close this one tomorrow
closed in favor of

: As I understand it, you initialize the docker image with the packages required by the packages in moveit.install of current branch HEAD. Doesn't that require to rebuild the docker image all the time? If not, who triggers the rebuild, if some changes to the dependencies happened?

The ci script again tries to install required dependencies with rosdep, doesn't it? But now it uses moveit.rosinstall of the current PR, correct? Isn't that somewhat redundant? Or is it this fact, which actually saves time?
Doesn't that require to rebuild the docker image all the time?
Yes, we have 13 containers that are being rebuilt for every commit to the corresponding branch - when a change occurs to

, 3 containers are rebuilt, same for jade, and for kinetic 4 because we have an experimental container now. However the containers all build on top each other (as of this PR) so they are more efficient
The ci script again tries to install required dependencies with rosdep, doesn't it?
Yes
But now it uses moveit.rosinstall of the current PR, correct?
Yes
Isn't that somewhat redundant?
Yes, unless a code change or PR introduces a new dependency that wasn't previously there in the Docker CI build. If no new dependencies exist, no new deps should be installed in the travis script.
Or is it this fact, which actually saves time?
This is what saves us the time, both in image size and download deps time.

Yes, would be nice to merge. The feature branch isn't merged because we need to deal with the fact that the Bullet version coming through apt on 16.04 is too old. I made a PR today to adapt cmake for this, see

I'm not sure, but is a regular 'merge' ok then?

If I'm understanding the role of this PR correctly, then I think we should just abandon this PR. Jens, is this PR/your fork's rebase-master branch is just to sync the ros-planning feature branch with master and handle resulting conflicts? If so, then we should forget about the ros-planning feature branch and just merge the feature into master from Jens' fork.

Dave can't rebase and merge because Jens' fork's feature branch is more up to date than the ros-planning feature branch and there is a merge conflict (probably between the feature commits in the ros-planning branch and the newer master commits that Jens' branch has but the ros-planning branch does not). And Jens doesn't have write access to ros-planning so he can't rebase the ros-planning feature branch directly (the reason for this PR). Potential solutions:
1- What I described above (simplest)

2- We use a merge commit to merge this PR into the ros-planning feature branch. So then we have a merge commit in the ros-planning feature branch history, and will potentially have another merge commit if we use a merge commit to merge this feature into master (unless we squash down the entire feature branch and try to rebase and merge)
3- If this PR contains no new features, then a maintainer can just merge it in and manually resolve any conflicts associated with the commit strategy (not an efficient use of maintainer time)
I just confirmed the rebase on
by force-pushing
to Jens' branch.
, I think the only? thing that prevents this feature branch from merging into master is
Sorry for the confusion, my only intent with the PR was to have
synced again to master and as I can't sync it directly (no write access) I created this PR. I am not sure why conflicts showed up though. Thanks
for handling this!
And yes, I think when
is handled we can merge the feature branch!
Thanks Robert, forgot about that option.

Jens, I think the rebase conflicts were there because the ros-planning feature branch had feature commits and your fork's branch also had those feature commits. So my guess is rebasing the feature commits individually with the rebase caused conflicts with the existing feature commits (which would explain why the merge commit strategy had no conflict).
Explanation for conflicts on github is simple: This PR was as rebase of original
branch onto master, but still targeting the (old)
branch. This naturally created conflicts. I manually force-pushed from the commandline.

pr_title: Use arrow markers for waypoints instead of circles
pr_contents: Using arrows instead of circles to shows the user robot's target pose (location and orientation)
This PR is a result of the conversation that I had with
a few weeks ago about how to use way point markers in a more efficient way.
PS: I guess I should have opened an issue about this first :)
It looks nice :) I used spheres because the angle in the intermediate waypoints was not required, but using the arrows improves the visualization. Good idea :)
the angle in the intermediate waypoints was not required

Just to understand better - the intermediate waypoints do have a 'pose' (position and orientation) correct? I am assuming, the robot would go to each waypoint (that particular position and orientation), and then go to the next one.
I am trying to understand what you mean by 'not required'
Hi
In the requirements section, in
it's written:
2.2. The robot need only have the correct orientation of the final pose.
My comment was referring to this.
Right now, if I am not wrong, it is implemented as a sequence of
actions, so orientation is relevant, and this enhancement is useful and cool. If
is a guideline for a future new implementation, maybe orientation is not suitable, and perhaps it could be unavailable.
Best

My only issue is that if you use arrows, I think the waypoint should be in the middle of the arrow, not on the base. I think that’s not a very intuitive visualization to have it at the end, even though that’s the easiest implementation solution
waypoint should be in the middle of the arrow, not on the base.

I think that is how it appears when you are giving the waypoints using RVIZ (at the base). So if we want to be consistent with how it appears in RVIZ while giving the goal, then we should keep it as it is.
Its not my first choice, but I’ll go with it
Making it middle of the arrow will not be intuitive either. It completely depends on what an arrow means to the user. There is not much I can do with the default markers, but here is another option.
I like that as a compromise.

I'm not convinced this is a good idea. There are lots of cases where a depth sensor can get depth dropouts, and maximum range is only one of those.
Does the depthimage format have any specific notations that differentiate between readings at the sensor's maximum range and depth points that are missing for another reason?
I think I agree with Austin, I see this as a regression against
, previously it did conform with "Erroneous detections shall be represented by quiet (non-signaling) NaNs" (which is what bad_point is).

Really, this should probably be implemented in the navigation stack, already the obstacle layer has "inf_is_valid" as a parameter, which "Allows for Inf values in "LaserScan" observation messages. The Inf values are converted to the laser maximum range."
and
are all correct.
With primesense devices (since the uint16_t format only has noresponse/error == 0), you end up having to use NaNs to clear the costmap.  Since this is reported as uints from the hardware
, I haven't found a way to determine the different cases.

However, it also reports all 0s if you say.... blocked the projector.  Or stepped into the deadband.  So if you step into the deadband, you were an obstacle at 0.5m, now you get cleared at 0.5m, and now the robots plans through you and can't sense you with the primesense.
Ultimately

is correct that this has to be implmented for the various cases people want by the nav stack.  Some hints may be adding other sensors like a laser rangefinder to cover the deadzone or some other approach you develop.
For image_pipeline this should be reverted because it will lead to clearly broken cases and isn't "a difference of implementation" between robots.

You're right when you say that there's no way to distinguish between the invalid readings coming from far away readings (no "echo"/"return") and close ones (blanking area). I'm happy that you've discussed about this.
The main problem of implemented this on the
observation buffers is that AFAIK there's no camera calibration information (principle point and focal distances) to compute the reprojection from the image plane (at the

) into the 3D PC. However, if anybody knows a clean (and efficient) way to implement this there, I'd be happy to do it. But still, the problem to distinguish far away from close invalid readings is still there. I'd say it's intrinsic to some sensors, but with this PR I tried to give the option (note that with
the implementation does the same as before) to have points for clearing in
I think you might have something to say here. I also have the following fundamental question: How does
manage the clearing when using PCs coming from RGBD sensors? I mean, when there's no reading because they're so far away, there's no endpoint to clear using raytracing, so AFAIK nothing is cleared.

RE: implementing "inf_is_valid" or "nan_is_valid" for point clouds in the costmap_2d: The camera info needed for the reprojection is in the camera_info topic (neither image nor point clouds contain the reprojection info).

You are correct that currently the costmap_2d does not currently implement "nan_is_clearing" or similar for point clouds, but I think the costmap_2d is the right place to implement that as an option -- not the image_pipeline. If you put it into the image pipeline, then it will affect all applications that depend on the particular point cloud you are modifying (which could cause all sorts of unintended side effects).

I concur with having this as part of costmap_2d. To keep layers from becoming too complicated, I would lean toward making a new layer to subscribe to DepthImages and CameraInfos.

For me it doesn't look like a new layer, but just like another observation source type.
Anyway, I have to look in more detail into it before implementing it.
I think implementing it as another observation source would be fine too.

pr_contents: This includes:
Can you clarify what you intend this new API to do and what the use case is that it's serving?
The purpose of this new API is to free the memory that is not used anymore because the frames are not used.

In my use case, I store frames shared_ptrs that are linked to a frame in the BufferCore. When their refcount reaches 0 because nobody is using them anymore, I would like to free them to avoid my bufferCore to basically leaking.
As I may create many "temporary" frames, it may result in lots of unused frames in memory.
This PR thus adds an erase() function to erase a frame from the BufferCore, and to do so refactors a bit the data structures used in the BufferCore to match this goal.
The goal is to have a way to erase the frames that are not needed anymore.
It frees memory.
This is especially useful if applications create temporary frames and uptimes are high.

Yeah, if there are a lot of temporary frames I can see that they might leak. However I'm not sure that the proposed 'erase' method is the best approach to this. This both breaks the premise of the cache which could potentially side effect other users of the Buffer, as well as requires the programmer to specifically track which frame_ids they want to clear.

I would suggest a simpler method which simply clears old data from the cache. As an optimization each linked list is only pruned on insert with respect to the cache duration. However it could easily be pruned at any time. A simple method cleanup cache could call the prune method for all frames given the current time. This would keep cache consistency during the valid period, but would clear old temporary transforms from memory. Adding this behavior as an automated periodic behavior that could be enabled might be worth considering too.
On the technical side. Looking forward (aka ROS2) we're moving away from using boost at all. And so restructuring to use a new boost datatype is not something that we want to do either.
Thanks for your answer, but I believe you suggestion does not quite match our need, as it will not free all the frames memory but only the transform data leaving dangling frames in memory.
erase() method is standard for a c++ container, and indeed requires programmers to track element lifetime. In our application, we are doing that using shared_ptrs above the BufferCore API.

To give you some figures about our use case, some client applications of our API can for example publish frames related to people detection up to 10 times per second, leading to a leak of a few decades of bytes each time, and a few megabytes per day. For a robot whose target uptime is in weeks, this is too much.

Regarding the boost container issue, the flat_map is knowingly more efficient for this kind of application but if it appears to be a blocking point, we might consider using std::unordered_map or some similar structure.

Are you actually seeing megabytes accumulating per day? If you're publishing 10 messages per second you should have a maximum of approximately 100 messages per frame id since the Cache discards old data once it is older than the cache duration, which defaults to 10 seconds. Thus you don't get continuous accumulation in long running applications.

For a long running application as I mentioned above the cache invalidation is done on a per frame_id basis. This could be generalized to clear the cache across all frame_ids periodically to clear previously published frames from the cache. With this improvement you will never have more than 100 messages per active frame_id and once a frame_id goes inactive the majority of it's data will be cleared within 10 seconds.

The BufferCore is not designed as a generic long term storage container. If you want to be doing that sort of thing there are a lot of optimizations that should be made rather than just adding an erase method to the core. Including decimating duplicate data, storing the data in queryable cointainer instead of a list. The choice of a list is to optimize data recording and from benchmarking is eqivalent in streaming data use cases. This is also why the Buffer is passed into the Listener and other APIs to allow you to provide a different implementation optimized for your use case.
Are you actually seeing megabytes accumulating per day?
Yes. Not because of new messages, but because of new
allocated
and
and never freed until BufferCore destruction.

Decimating has nothing to do with our problem, we are not concerned by clearing frame buffers but rather by clearing frames themselves. By the way we kept the default buffer duration and it is fine with our usage. Adding an erase() is necessary and sufficient to solve our problem.
Maybe you haven't encountered this problem already because it has not been used in application creating many frames (and not only new messages).

Can you clarify what scale of "many" you are talking about when you say "many frames"? Empty caches should use on the order of 10s of bytes each. The empty caches either have one Transform stored inside them or a linked list of transforms.

But either way I would still not want to try to support arbitrary modifications of the active buffer that could potentially side effect other lookups inside the valid cache time. My above suggestion of a method that clears old data could also deallocate the (Static)TimeCache(s) if they are found to be empty after pruning.
Alright, I am not sure about what you mean by the "arbitrary modifications" but I understand that you are not comfortable with merging this PR.
Efficiently managing memory is too important in our use case, so we will find a way around this issue.
Thanks for your time anyway! :)

pr_title: Replace spinonce() in loop with simple spin()
pr_contents: This appears to be much more efficient. With spinonce() in a while loop, each
node (allocator and estimator) would run a core at 100 % cpu. Using simply spin(), the processes use very little cpu when idle.
Seems to be a better and more common practice.
Hi Takahiro,
This is a nice contribution. Thank you.

I'll check it in detail on Monday. But first thing that came to mind when I had a look at the code is: did you consider using the octree filter implementation from libpointmatcher? It allows you to perform the same operation as the PCL VoxelGridFilter, but with the advantage that it can output a set of

, which are points that belong to the point cloud, instead of geometric centroids. Given the fact that elevation mapping tries to approximate the floor shape by means of a distribution, you need the points from the point cloud to be accurate and representative, so I think it could be beneficial to explore this.
Have a nice weekend!
Best,
Yoshua

Hey
, thanks for the contribution.

I was wondering why you chose a voxel grid filter. I think that the point cloud produced by the RealSense already has a quite uniform density, and therefore we could as well use a random downsampling filter. This filter would be much faster than using a voxel grid, while not making the density heterogeneous.
What are your thoughts on that?

I think a more systematic way to filter the point cloud is nice to have. By setting the voxel size you can kind of compare it to the size of the grid map, e.g., you want to make sure that the voxel size is smaller than the grid size.
I think that the voxel grid filter is better to not lose information about the terrain.
I think it can be used unless the computation time of the filtering becomes a big issue.

I am not sure if you are aware of the filter_and_merger node on ANYmal, which takes point clouds from various sources (Velodyne, RealSense(s)), filters and merges them. I think in the context of ANYmal, it could make sense to process the point clouds there, such that other nodes can profit from the outcome as well.
Yes, it also makes sense to filter in the more primitive node.
Since this filtering is just an option, if we use the filtering before, we can disable the voxel grid filter in the elevation mapping, and if not, we can enable it.
I think this filtering feature can be beneficial for those who only use raw point cloud as input or don't want to lose information for the other processes.
I agree with Takahiro. It is just an additional feature that can be turned on and off. In our case, we will use the voxel filter. You are welcome to use filter_and_merger node for your purposes.
I am in general fine with the changes, we need to get
's opinion once he is back next Monday.
: Can you please have a look?
Please address the open issues before we can merge this. Also, documentation is missing.
I measured the computation time for
The number of points.
The average calculation time with 100 measurements.
So, adding the voxel grid filter reduced the computation time to 1 / 3.44

Thanks for this, it's obvious that by removing points the process will be faster. Another comparison should be done by skipping every n'th point when processing the point cloud. This seems like a nicer solution then structuring the point cloud twice, once for the voxel filter and then again for the elevation mapping.

Thanks for this, it's obvious that by removing points the process will be faster. Another comparison should be done by skipping every n'th point when processing the point cloud. This seems like a nicer solution then structuring the point cloud twice, once for the voxel filter and then again for the elevation mapping.

I think it is nicer to structure the point cloud twice. The skipping of the points is less intuitive for tuning and depens on the point cloud size and the grid map size. By structuring the point cloud with voxels requires only to compare the size of the voxels with the grid map size. In addition, by skipping points you lose information from areas where you do not have a dense point cloud, e.g., terrain which is far away.
I think there is a trade-off in skipping method as well as downsampling filter and voxel filtering method.
In the skipping method, it can compute faster but has an accuracy decrease. It does not care about the geometry so it may use the noisy data and discard the remaining points in some cells.
The voxel filter calculates the centroid in each voxel so it can capture the structure more accurately.
So, each filtering methods have each feature and can be selected depends on the application.
How about considering that this pull request is to add a voxel grid filter, and other filtering methods can be added in another pull request?

Please take a look
This PR is a work in progress; I intend to expand a little more on what I did and why it should replace what's already here.
This pull request represents a complete re-write of the

data structure that underlies Descartes' existing planners. It strips away much of the abstraction that was previously there and focuses on storing the vast amount of graph data in a compact fashion that mirrors the actual problem that we solve.

I tried a lot of small ways to fix various issues that really bugged me in Descartes' existing code. After a lot of proto-typing and internal debate, I decided that to achieve the speed, space efficiency, and correctness that I wanted would require me to drop the use of boost graph altogether.
The highlights are (for larger search problems with many edges):
These comparisons are made with respect to the current
branch and DO NOT take into account the cost of collision checking. That dominates everything, and we'll need a different approach to make that more manageable.
The biggest change introduced by this PR is the replacement of the
graph with a custom graph type called a
Previously, Descartes used several structures to represent data:

All of this indirection comes with a cost.  The last item has to be recomputed every time a modification is done to the graph because all of the vertex descriptors are invalidated when the graph changes.
The new algorithm has one data structure (psuedo-code):

This directly stores the information we care about with just about no redundancy or extra overhead. A vertex can be accessed through an indirect read without having to do any extra lookups. Mutating the graph is also cheap, as rungs can be swapped without copying the underlying data using C++11 move semantics.
The new graph makes some assumptions:
Furthermore this structure emphasizes graph mutation that changes everything at a rung level. If we wanted to remove individual joint points, it would require some additional work and
be less efficient for that.

Dijkstra's search algorithm is currently used to search the graph. This PR does not change that, but provides a custom implementation of it to work directly with our existing graph. I attempted to keep the existing boost graph algorithm by
, but the adapter code, particularly the iterators, ended up being longer than the actual implementation of the search.
The search is based on the existing
and uses Boost's BinaryHeap to efficiently implement a priority queue.
The above chart shows the relative speed and memory improvements of solving:
The graph was solved at different angular discretizations shown along the bottom. The y value represents the time/space consumption of this PR relative to indigo-devel.

This does a lot of redundant work with the cost computation, also called in the hot loop:
Also the
is the same for all joints associated with a given user input point (because they all share a single timing constraint).

Long story, short: If codify the idea we will test for joint velocity limits directly into the planner we can get another 1.3 to 2x speed improvement depending on the graph size. This change involves adding a
to the robot model.
With these changes, OMP can be used to completely parallelize the graph building using three extra lines of code (plus some config file changes). I saw 3-4x speed improvements from this.

pr_title: Improve efficiency of sparse matrix initialization
pr_contents: Problem setup takes a very long time when the number of affine expressions is very large, for example if there are many link pairs that could be in collision and multiple costs or constraints are assigned per pair. I'd like to benchmark this more thoroughly, but as an example a problem with about 5000 variables and 10000 constraints took about 60s to set up and then about 1 second to solve.
The reason for this is that the function for composing Eigen sparse matrices from affine expression vectors uses a very inefficient method for inserting new elements.
, the
function performs a binary search on the matrix when inserting each new element to make sure that there is not already an element at the specified row and column. Additionally, the
function composes a separate sparse vector for each row in the sparse matrix, which increases the number of calls to
. Since
is
where
is the number of nonzero elements in each matrix row (from
), creating a sparse matrix in this way with
rows and
elements per row is (I think):
A better way to create a sparse matrix while ensuring good performance is to compose a list of triplets containing
and then convert that into a matrix using
, which is
where
is the number of triplets (from
). For a sparse matrix with
rows and
elements per row this would be:
This PR modifies the version of
most frequently used by the OSQP interface to use triplets, which greatly reduces the setup time for large problems. In my example case, the problem can now be set up in less than 0.5s.

pr_title: Fix bug in eigenvalues classifying points
pr_contents: Eigen::SelfAdjointEigenSolver docs say: Only the lower triangular part of the input matrix is referenced.
The original code was filling the upper triangular part.
As a result, the obtained eigenvalues were actually... the diagonal elements, while totally ignoring their correlation.
In practice: the original code was not doing its job while classifying point patches that were not at 90 degrees with the (arbitrary) XYZ axes.
Hi, a question: why not do a

on the 3x5 data matrix with the subtracted centroid from every column? The first column of U contains the dominant line, while the third contains the normal. This is also the method described in the original loam paper.
Hmm.... what 3x5 matrix? I guess you meant 3x3, right?
You're right, the SVD method would also work, and is probably more numerically stable, but my patch just fixed the original LOAM code which uses Eigen::SelfAdjointEigenSolver :-)
Anyway, it should be benchmarked to decide whether it really represents a significant improvement in either speed or accuracy...

Nope, 3x5 :) 5 points are drawn from the kd tree to which we want to fit a line or a plane. If you stack them in columns, you get a 3 (xyz) by 5 (column for each point) data matrix. Compute and subtract the centroid from each column and fire up SVD. The result is really elegant - the 3x3 U of the decomposition has the line direction and plane normal as the first and third columns.
More details in
Ah, ok now I got your idea! Sure, it's a good approach... should be benchmarked to check if it's more or less efficient than the current one...

pr_title: Service to query trajectory segments from the pose graph.
pr_contents: This
service allows to look up trajectory segments
from the pose graph.
This can be useful if one wants to get optimized trajectory data from
the current SLAM run and listening to live TF data would be too noisy.
For example, to stitch buffered point cloud data from a depth sensor
based on a recent localization trajectory segment of a robot.
Before, the pose graph trajectory nodes were not available except for
the trajectory marker topic (only positions, no orientation; inefficient)
or after serialization (which is not practical in live operation).

This needs some thread synchronization. The kinematic parameters are used on a different thread than the reconfigure call back.
The simple fix would be to add a mutex to the
class that we take in
and every function that accesses these parameters. However, that's not going to be very efficient; every parameter has an individual accessor method.
Instead this class should be refactored so clients can grab the set of parameters instead of individual parameters.
However, that's not going to be very efficient; every parameter has an individual accessor method.
Aren't the callbacks triggered by a ros thread spinning? If we're using single threaded executors (which we are), this is going to be already be thread safe, right?
The callbacks run in the context of the ros spin function, but the actions runs on their own thread. So, in this case, all the FollowPath logic is on it's own thread, independent of the callbacks.
Here's where the thread is kicked off:

Line 134
      in
All our action servers run this way, so it is something we need to watch out for mostly everywhere.

Got it. Another option is to just make all the variables atomic. I know atomic doubles don't "technically" exist, but the template will work fine for our purposes because we're not using the operators on the values, they're just being stored and retrieved.
Yeah. You're right. Atomics would be a better option than taking the mutex everywhere.

I'm not sure where the cutoff lies between the cost of accessing many atomics and the cost of taking one mutex. I suspect we're approaching that in this class though, so I think refactoring the interface makes sense in the long run.
Just making them all atomic though, would be a good short term fix and may be good enough that we never need to come back to the long run fix :-)

42x, it appears from that dummy example. I'm actually a little surprised to see much overhead at all from just reading, I thought atomics were programmed to check for a condition that would make it near-zero overhead when something wasn't actively trying to write.
I believe they do memory fence instructions to force writes all the way out to cache and reads to refresh from cache, at least on x86
This is going to impose some overhead and it might vary depending on how much data is in the write buffers and, ... well, I'm a bit fuzzy on exactly what a read fence does. :-)

pr_contents: Related to issue
and Issue

, here is my first crack at adding time windowing data to our trajectory points. First off, this pull-request is not quite ready because there are many documentation changes that need to be made but I would like to get eyes on this asap.

This PR replaces the Point Transition class with a timing constraint struct that has an upper and lower limit for time. Only the upper limit on time is currently used or checked (I'm not sure if the lower is needed). This timing must be specified when building new types of Trajectory Points but it can be default constructed which puts the upper and lower limits to zero.
Planning graph has been changed to incorporate pull request

as well as to remove the absolute joint delta check in place of an updated function in RobotModel that takes two joint positions and a time delta and sees if motion between those two points is possible in that window of time.
Again this is under development, but I want to see if people think I'm on the track.

Something for us to consider: a fully specified joint state would specify the position and velocity for each point.  Acceptable trajectories would require less than than maximum joint velocities and accelerations between points.  The current planner only considers positions and ignores dynamics (velocities and accelerations).  This pull adds time constraints thereby permitting calculation of average velocities along a trajectory.  In the limit as the step size approaches zero, the average and the instantaneous velocities are the same.  The question is: should we instead specify velocities at points, thereby permitting us to calculate accelerations to achieve the trajectory?  Or should we look at the second (numerical) derivative to calculate accelerations?

UPDATE: I think the above is flawed, because we can't know the joint velocities ahead of time.  All we know is time, so calculating the average velocity is the best we can do.  I guess there is still the question of whether we should also calculate the average acceleration?

Perhaps also something to keep in mind (or to purposefully ignore): a lot (some?) industrial robot controllers work with trajectory segments, where you can specify a target velocity to be reached over that segment, not at the end point. With blending/falling through/contouring/x, you can get the controller to smoothly stitch segments together, but at the cost of accuracy (in both time and space, I believe). Making the segments small enough can work around this in some way, but (in most cases) at the cost of maximum attainable performance.

I've always considered this more position control with velocity constraints over traj segments than actually being able to define the state of the manipulator (pose & velocity) at specific points. ROS generated trajectories seem to assume we can actually do the latter. I think only the
driver is currently capable of that within ros-i.
Is this something we want to keep in mind? Or is
being designed
, where all industrial controllers provide full access to their motion control systems?
I agree with
in that it is probably best to consider it as position control with velocity constraints and rather than a true velocity controller, so the current approach seems like the pragmatic and right one.

Related, a filter could be applied post-planning that generates a smooth velocity trajectory.  Here is the classic cubic spline equation which requires as inputs pos_0, pos_1, t_0, t_1, and vel_0 to calculate the smooth velocity at the trajectory endpoint, vel_1. A similar approach could be used if we wanted to specify joint velocities.
from: Spong et. al., "Robot Modeling and Control", 2005

, it sounds like you are OK with the current approach.  I would like provide a little bit of the total vision (this will eventually make it's way to the REP).  When considering trajectories, Descartes will contain two types of trajectories:
Initially
and I chose timing because it generalizes to any kind of point.  Therefore, it can exist in the base
type.  I believe this was Clay's conclusion as well.  The one possible downside to this change implies a direction to the motion (i.e. a
from the previous point).  A
approach was chosen to allow an upper and lower bound to be specified (kind of like the pose constraints).  Not sure how to avoid the implied direction of motion.
To

's second point, the joint trajectory that results from planning will have to be smoothed.  If the graph used for planning does not contain edges or nodes that are physically impossible, then a smooth trajectory through the planned trajectory is likely possible.  Unfortunately, there are some trajectory conditions, like path reversals, which are not considered at pruning time.  This is a known limitation at this time.
One final thought,

and I discussed using instantaneous velocities at a point to determine if the point (and therefore the node) is valid.  Using this PR's method of pruning edges is good, but removing a node entirely is much better.  I believe I understand how to generalize this to both cart/joint points.  This will be a future PR.
For smoothing, can
be useful?
, this PR can't be merged automatically...can you rebase to fix this?
I rebased the code, but there is still the outstanding issue of making the timing work with the sparse trajectory planner. I'll look into that shortly.
or
If y'all would take a look at this again when you have a chance, I'd appreciate it.
, please review
Code reviews aren't fun.  Just a few minor comments but in general this one is ready to merge
Would like feedback on this.
Is this an acceptable validity check? Is it ever concealable we'll have negative time values?
I think an assert statement is too drastic a measure.  If the timing constraint is incorrectly specified then the
method could just return false.  Whether planning proceeds or aborts based on this condition should be up to the planner.
I removed the assertion and replaced it with a warning. In the event of invalid (read negative) timing values, the times are instead set to zero indicating unspecified.
pr_details_more: Dense trajectory (currently implemented) - A dense trajectory is defined point by point.  A trajectory point (joint/cart/whatever) will contain a pose, with associated velocity, acceleration, and timing.  I realize this could be over/under constrained depending how many derivatives you think are required.  A key requirement is that motion in between trajectory points is well defined (i.e. smooth and collision free).
Sparse trajectory (in progress, see start in PR
) - This could be any number of representations.  It could look like traditional robot code (as

pointed out), gcode, or anything.  In general, these trajectories will contain points and segment constrains (linear, circular, joint, velocity, timing, etc...).  These representations are efficient, but there is no guarantee that motion segments are well behaved and/or is collision free.  Sparse trajectories must be converted to dense trajectories for planning.  This conversion depends on the representation used, but should result in populated velocity, acceleration, and timing values.

pr_contents: This PR add CI support for CircleCI.

Like Travis, CircleCI is a Continuous Integration service, however CircleCI provides more docker integration such as support for custom images without resorting to machine type executors. This means that CI jobs can start as soon as they are triggered, rather than queuing for an available Virtual Machine to then spin up. The pulling of the Docker Image is perhaps the only main flat overhead in triggering jobs. Further features such as caching and storage of artifacts additionally accelerate job times while providing insight into build and test results.

The proposed CI would start with pre-build Docker Image, hosted on automated repo on Docker Hub that would trigger tag builds upon new commits into particular GitHub branches or rebuilds of linked Docker Hub repos, i.e.
base image. Built tags would include all/most the necessary dependencies for the project, include any build dependencies for prerequisite dependencies, i.e. running
, etc. on the master branch. Even when short cutting the install time by building
the
base image, this takes about 90 min on Docker Hub, so it helpful to offload/bake this amount of setup into the image our CI pulls from.
Once the CI pulls the docker image above, the config proceeds to clean the workspaces and checkout the source to inspect. This also entails

ing and prerequisite defined in the new checked out source, installing the prerequisite dependencies, building the prerequisites themselves, installing the source packages dependencies, building the source packages, then testing the source packages.

In between steps in the job of the workflow, caching of the build stages for both prerequisite and source packages is attempted. Caches are broken with either the installed dependencies change or the source code has changed. This allows the cache to persist across jobs.
An example of current table of caching in action:
Lastly, the log files for the colcon build and test steps are also archived and made linkable by storing them with the job's public artifacts.
DockerHub
CircleCI
Is the performance gain largely because you've switched to CircleCI or is it because you're starting from
? If we switch to CircleCI, do we still need to have Travis as well, or can we do everything within Circle to keep things simpler?
Is the performance gain largely because you've switched to CircleCI or is it because you're starting from ruffsl/navigation2:master?

, its partly both. Most of the upfront time is saved by starting from a Docker Image prepped for the CI with common dependence pre-installed, but then some more is also saved by making use of the caching between jobs. We could perhaps save even more by enabling
, but this currently seems to be a premium feature from CircleCI.
If we switch to CircleCI, do we still need to have Travis as well, or can we do everything within Circle to keep things simpler?

Well, I'm not sure. You could have both if you wanted, don't think it would be much drain. You might want to have only one or the other CI enabled for PRs to prevent too much integration noise. CircleCI might be better for this, as long as we can keep the quick turnaround times I've tabled above.
I'm not sure Travis has the same
as CircleCI, so it may still be well suited for longer builds via periodic cron jobs. E.g. just rebuilding the whole Dockerfile daily via master branch and run the stock tests and code coverage.
Also ping
, I've updated the top PR comment with more details.

I'll admit I don't understand the details of docker cache breaks yet, but I see no harm in adding Circle CI. It would definitely be nice to have faster feedback from the CI system, and it seems to best way to get a feel for Circle vs Travis is to turn this on and get some experience with both side by side.

pr_title: audio_play: Fix mp3 clip overlap by never pausing the pipeline
pr_contents: We were seeing an issue when publishing mp3 clips.  The tail end of each clip was cut off and applied to the beginning of the next clip with varying intensity (but a short clip was almost always lost entirely).
It looked like the

event was causing a pipeline pause before the rest of the pipeline was drained.  Manually draining the pipeline seemed like a real chore, so I removed the pipeline pausing feature and set a property on the source allowing for the kind of ad hoc input we intend to feed it.

Hi there!
As part of an internship for
, I've been in charge of investigating various 3D SLAM algorithms for autonomous driving.

Cartographer caught my attention and I was led to do a bunch of experiments with it for the past couple of weeks. I started out as a complete ROS and SLAM newbie and I think I stumbled upon just enough difficulties to get a global overview of Cartographer and identify some problems with its documentation.

I was able to find most of the info I needed spread across Cartographer's source code, paper, GitHub issues, PRs, RFCs, Open House slides, commit log and documentation. It is relatively easy to find what most of the parameters are and do but I found it quite hard to "connect the dots" and see the bigger picture of how the many subsystems relate to each others. This led me to believe that information around Cartographer currently

While looking at GitHub issues, I was also able to isolate a few things that you keep on repeating over and over again when users want to get started with Cartographer. (for instance: rosbag validation,
, how to report an issue properly and so on...) I believe it also underlines a
for some of the basic features Cartographer has to offer.
When looking at the documentation, I also found out that some parts were
. For instance, the supported ROS distributions or the .lua configuration reference or the ROS API (which I haven't changed because there is another pending PR for this).
Therefore, I decided to address those issues by writing down the knowledge I have gathered and contribute it back to the project.

The "Algorithm walkthrough" page is quite ambitious: I'm sure I failed to understand and explain some of the most intertwined concepts used in Cartographer. (for instance: I think I still have troubles understanding the structure of hybrid probability grids) I really hope that your review will pinpoint the parts I could have misunderstood and help me understand what still isn't clear to me. So please let me know if you notice anything wrong and I'll do my best to correct the PR accordingly.
Thanks a lot!

P.S: On a more personal note, I also happen to be an open-source project maintainer in my free time and I found Cartographer's openness remarkable. The way you handle Open House sessions and RFCs blew me away, congratulations! If you ever happen to go to FOSDEM, I'll make sure I'll buy you a beer.

the first goal of this PR is to restructure the current doc from a "reference documentation" (with only sparse and low level pieces of information) to a "zero to hero guide" (a structured step-by-step tutorial for both newcomers and experimented users)
I took some liberty to rework the current documentation to propose a structure that makes sense to me.
You could, of course, disagree with those changes and propose something else.
the second goal of this PR is to provide in-depth information on how to get started with Cartographer and how to understand its parameters.

This led to the creation of the "Running Cartographer ROS on your own bag" page explaining how to get started with Cartographer and the "Algorithm walkthrough" page providing a step-by-step guide to Cartographer

the rest of this PR is either cosmetic (title changes for clarity) or provides some basic conveniences (a short contributor guide or pointers to advanced features such as gRPC, IMU calibration and so on...)

One feature that would be very helpful for deploying this on robots, and making it easier on applications developers to hop from robot to robot, is the notion of a set of system/platform defaults, so that a robot manufacturer may easily set the default set of capabilities that should be preferred when not overwritten by a particular preference passed by an app.
For instance, almost every robot will implement the

capability, but will do so in their own package/launch file, setting important parameters and configurations for that robot. As an application developer, your application should be able to run on any of these robots, and simply ask for "Navigation" and get the proper config for the robot.

I'm not sure how we want to implement these -- should they be parameters to the capabilities server? That way, when the main robot launch file that brings up drivers/roscore is launched, you've set the defaults.
Are you talking about parameters?

My thinking on this would be that any configuration of the capabilities on the robot side would be done through an application developers code which used dynamic parameters. The dynamic_reconfigure parameters have defaults, descriptions and ranges defined already, I guess I was thinking app developers would lean on this for these kinds of configuration interactions with capabilities.
No, I'm talking about which
is the default one for the robot, i.e. if someone installs turtlebot_navigation on my robot, I still want the provider found in my_robot_navigation to be the default one used on my_robot
I see. Yeah, I am still working out how complex the provider preference system will be, and then how it will work.
I'll keep this in mind.

I've update the title to make it a bit clearer what I was talking about. I think this really is an important aspect if we want this to be widely adopted as an easy way for applications to be able to support many different robots (and at the same time not have to completely lock down the system such that non-default providers ever get installed).
Preferences for providers should definitely be added.
I see the robot developer in charge of setting up a reasonable config. I.e.
should set the default/preferred
capability provider to

. If later someone decides to install additional navigation software, it would just add another capability provider for navigation. It would also be that person's job to update the minimal configuration accordingly - either deciding that the default/preferred provider is still
or the new one.
I am considering using rosparams for setting the default providers, something like
setting
to
will indicate to the
which default provider to use.
Thoughts? Is there a need for more sophisticated configuration?
For configuration that should be ok. On the capability server side we probably need to introduce some logic and checks for the case, that multiple providers are available but no default chosen.
E.g. pop up a warning, which contains which provider has been chosen, or just an error and shut down the server.
what should the behavior be?
Should the check occur at startup or at runtime of a capability?
Should the check produce a warning (choosing some arbitrary default at runtime) or an error?
How should we handle capabilities without providers available?
For capabilities with only one provider, should we:
I would lean towards the simple and explicit policy:
At startup, any capability interfaces with providers available and no default provider configuration will produce an error and exit. Capabilities with no providers will be ignored.
Should the check occur at startup or at runtime of a capability?
For now we don't target runtime reconfiguration of capabilities. Hence one check at startup is enough.
At startup, any capability interfaces with providers available and no default provider configuration will produce an error and exit. Capabilities with no providers will be ignored.
I like this. We could add, that if only one provider is available, we only show a warning. It's a bit redundant to setup a default provider, if only one is available/configured.
Ok, I'll try to implement this today.

just to be sure. Thoughts?

not from me

To just one warning, I'd say. But that is just cosmetics.

pr_title: Fix "no valid trajectories" when obstacle on path
pr_contents: Merging
into

To be fair, if you're close enough to the goal to have sensor coverage to see that the goal requested is invalid, I think failing to produce velocity commands is a fair option, so that recovery behaviors can be initiated to try to clear out that area or redefine the goal into a close-by but valid space. I've gotten around this in the past with asynchronous watchdogs but that's a different story.

I wouldn't want a robot to charge to the goal if it could make a better decision earlier on. An example in warehousing might be that there's already a robot  (or person) in that spot, if the robot didn't stop 2-10m out to make a decision about what to do next, the robot would get very close to that other robot (or human) making it challenging for the robot to get out of the way for the new one (or get uncomfortably close to the human).

Aside from that, if you don't think this optimization is worthwhile, I'd just remove the entire function or comment it out so that we don't have a function doing nothing where someone might think it does something.
I think failing to produce velocity commands is a fair option

Our thinking was that the global planner is in a better position to make this decision. In the case that there is an obstacle on the goal, the global planner will fail on the next replan and a recovery can take place.

However, some configurations do not have replanning enabled at a rate. The 2 main ways of replanning are to replan at a constant rate, and to replan only when the controller fails to produce velocity commands. The controller must fail to trigger a replan
Looks good, just one minor style suggestion for consideration.
Since we're currently pruning the goal since

, it would seem that we get this issue of no valid trajectories when the pruned goal hits an obstacle, correct? I think since we have re-planning enabled, this is seen less often. If it does happen, then I would think it occurs when nav_fn has yet to update dwb with a clear path before the controller fails. Given this was originally a check to largely help performance (and ensure goal is still valid), I don't know if I'd consider this a bug or flaw, at least before we introduced the pruned goals.
it would seem that we get this issue of no valid trajectories when the pruned goal hits an obstacle, correct?
That is correct.
If it does happen, then I would think it occurs when nav_fn has yet to update dwb with a clear path before the controller fails
I believe that is correct.
I don't know if I'd consider this a bug or flaw

There are two critics involved here. Let's look at them independently, and let's look at the GoalAlign critic first since I believe the answer is clear in that case. Let's also ignore the path pruning we introduced for now and assume the goal is truly the end goal the user requested.
- The goal align critic works by transforming the goal pose to an new pose some distance away - 0.325m by default. See the code

. It then reuses the GoalDist critic mechanism to score the trajectory using that new point as if it were the goal. As a result, this critic will reject all trajectories when a certain point 0.325m from the goal is occluded, even if the goal itself is free. I feel that is unambiguously bad.

- So let's say the user has requested the robot go to the center of a room. The robot rounds the corner and finds the center point occupied. What should the robot do? Without this change it stops. Ideally, a replan happens and we resume navigating to a point next to the obstacle. With this change, it continues navigating to a point next to the obstacle without stopping. My preference is to give the global planner a chance to replan while keeping the robot in motion as much as possible. I feel this is more in spirit with what DWA is supposed to address. It's supposed to keep the robot doing something sensible till the next plan is generated. If we want to stop if there is an obstacle, we may as well use a simpler PID controller to keep us on the path at all times, IMHO. I feel like we should have a controller like that by the way. I'm not dissing that approach.

pr_details_more: There is a flaw in the Goal* critics that cause them to reject valid trajectories. This is most easily reproduced by "navigating to pose" and then dropping an obstacle onto the path some distance ahead of the robot. DWB will fail well before it reaches the obstacle saying no valid trajectories were found.

The root cause is in the way the Goal* critics expand their cost function. They add a 0 cost goal cell and then expand out from their add 1 to the cost at each step. However there is an optimization in the expansion that skips cells that are invalid. When the goal itself is invalid, absolutely no cells get enqueued and the Goal* critics think every trajectory hits an unknown area.

This PR removes that optimization. It's still a WIP because I'd like to fix this in a way that doesn't hurt performance, but if there is no time, I'd like to still add this PR as is to the dashing release because it fixes a fairly major bug.

pr_title: Added a precharge check before transitioning into MOVING state. Witho…
pr_contents: Grizzly exhibits stuttering when transitioning from Stopped to Moving while a constant cmd_vel is being streamed to it. This is because the state machine is transitioning from STARTING to MOVING before the precharge completes.

The wait time is currently hard coded at 2.0s, but sometimes the precharge can take longer. This PR adds a check to ensure that the precharge has finished before the state machine transitions to MOVING.

電源に関する何かしらのプログラムがｃでもｖでもどちらでもOKとすると、
いろいろ依存関係やOSのバージョンなど考慮して、ｃよりｖの方が管理がラクなように思います。
僕のイメージだと，基盤があって，それが現在の電圧，電流，残り時間を出してくれて，readするだけでよくて，それがioボード経由か
シリアル／USB経由かはわからないけど，そういう状況にているので，電源に関するプログラム，というのは存在しなくて，readするだけ．
hrpsysのエマージェンシーは議論が続いている気がするけど，電源低下もその一種なのでこれが起こればemergencyとして，
サーボオフするなり，warningだすなりする機能が考えられる．エンコーダのトビがあったら止まる，とか，バランスを崩していたら止まる，
とか，足裏が擦れていたら止まるとか，そういうのは最下層のプログラムで行われるべき事柄．コリジョンチェックも最下層で行われている．
そのデータはros経由でパブリッシュされてなんか見ることはできるだろうし，そのパブリッシュされた結果をみて中するプログラムもあるだろうけど，それは色々可能性がある．
最下層のプログラムは，落ちたら終わりなので，かなり丁寧に作ってデバッグも最優先．
それ以外の上のプログラムはまぁ落ちてもよいかというレベル．
電源は最下層部分だろうから（とはいえ電源がないときに何ができるかは，ないかもしれないけど），それは最下層の部分に入れておくべき．
現状のシステムで最下層はhrpsys本体．ROSの通信がつながらない，外部のPCのホスト名が引けない，いろいろあったとしても，体内のCは
動き続けていることが期待される．

pr_contents: These changes make the battery diagnostics node (voltage monitor and emailer) more flexible, allowing compatibility with both segbot_v2 and segbot_v3. These changes include:
I've added a couple of minor comments. Is there a process to setting up the sendmail stuff on a computer? Does it need to be documented on the wiki?
I addressed your comments with
. Let me know if you have others
The sendmail setup script is located at: segbot_sensors/sendmail_configure.sh.

It pretty much takes care of everything. The script only needs to be run once and is written such that the external email & password are not stored in plaintext. Consequently, the one running the script will need to enter the external email & password during the sendmail setup process.
The password shouldn't be documented on the wiki (obviously) but I will add some instructions regarding the battery monitor & emailer.
Thanks Max!
This commit adds the battery monitor to v3. As such, I believe the v3 is now up-to the v2 functionality.
Looks good to me.
There is a new
message we should probably migrate to at some point, but that's a separate issue.
I like the way Max was able to combine the battery monitoring and launch scripts for the two models.
Well done!

lgtm.
Does this launch file stay separated from any other launch file and should this be launched somehow by default from
Hi Karsten,
As it is a pretty new feature, available on NAOqi2.5.2+ only, I would keep it separated from other launch files and make it available for users to launch it.
Note that naoqi2.5/libqi2.5 is available only on ros kinetic (not Jade and
indigo if I remember well) so we may want to branch out at that point.
As a side notes the KneePitch mesh should already be available in the
pepper_meshes package and were not officially "publicly releasable without
licence" according to Aldebaran. Maybe the legal position changed in that
since.
Otherwise LGTM
On Sep 20, 2016 9:22 AM, "Lucas Souchet"
wrote:
Hi Karsten,
As it is a pretty new feature, available on NAOqi2.5.2+ only, I would keep
it separated from other launch files and make it available for users to
launch it.

or mute the thread
You are right about the meshes, they are not mandatory here, I'll just remove them from the PR and check  again internally.

As for the 2.5 compatibility, I don't know how it is versionned on your side. I tested it on indigo locally with a NAOqi 2.5 and it works, probably because I only use old libqi calls. So I am not sure branching is mandatory here.
Is there a way to check for the libqi version at the beginning of your script? Would make sense to print an error message in case they use the wrong version. What do you think?
Regarding the meshes, we can add the pod mesh to

with all the other ones and this way it can be displayed in rviz with your plugin. That package explicitly ask the user to accept the licence agreement before installing the meshes so we should be good.

It doesn't really rely on libqi version, but more on NAOqi version, it don't think there is an easy way of knowing that. Perhaps I could differentiate the exception between a "such method does not exist because your NAOqi version is too old" and "I am not currently localized, hence I cannot publish anything". Don't know if it is easy either though. What do you think?
I'll check with my hierarchy, I'll probably submit it in a later PR. Thanks anyway.
any update? Would you consider merging it?
Thanks!
, maybe you want to announce it on the SIG. Maybe it is related to:
Also, is 2.5.2 released ? I think there was a way to check for NAOqi's version, something like naoqi.
but not as clean. Also, you could try an import of what you need and show a warning message for any error.
I'll look for a way of handling the naoqi version.
I was planning on announcing it once the 2.5.2 was officially released.

libqi2.5 is indeed only available on kinetic, but is actually not necessary here. Different versions of libqi are totally able to communicate (meaning libqi2.3 on your desktop and libqi 2.5 on the robot can understand each other, and the other way around too).
Checking the naoqi version makes sense, but as long as the robot is on the correct version, this code should work for every ROS distro.
2.5 seems out
, maybe an announcement would be nice now ?

Hi,
, I'd like to test this newly merged function of yours.
For this, I think I need bag files containing can_info (CAN messages).
I've recorded many bag files which normally include images (from a camera), pointcloud (with a LiDAR) and nmea sentences (by a GNSS); however, they've never had CAN messages yet.
I have my own test vehicle as large as ZMP RoboCar MV2, whose internal communications are all done via CAN.
Would you introduce how to record CAN messages (along with other signals from other sensors)?
FYI, I have the KVASER Leaf as a CAN interface.
Thank you for reading,
Hi,
You need to convert CAN messages to autoware_msgs::can_info by yourself. Autoware does not have any function for the converting.
If you successfully convert and publish them, you can record the can_info topic.
Thanks for your reply, @cirpue49 :)
In vehicle_receiver.cpp, can_info topic is being published -
ros::Publisher can_pub = nh.advertise<autoware_msgs::CanInfo>("can_info", 100);
It tells the ROS master that a message of type autoware_msgs\CanInfo is being published on the can_info topic.
This is followed by
can_pub.publish(can_msg);
, which is included in getCanValue function.
I'm wondering (in getCanValue function) there is no code written to input some (CAN) values to can_msg, which should be implemented as
can_msg.____ = values;
Instead, there are just
can_msg.header.frame_id = "/can";
can_msg.header.stamp = ros::Time::now();
These two are considered very few by comparing with a message of type autoware_msgs\CanInfo; CanInfo.msg contains

pr_contents: The mixing and scaling that occurs for manual does not need to happen for auto
Re added the gaurd that prevented this
Left the capping of inputs outside the gaurd as a temp fix to overvolting/overamping that the motors where causing.
There is no need to change the max_motor_cmd for this bug fix but I have added the remainder of the fix. Thanks,
Added voltage divider values to ru and en articles
Please review,
Additional MCU msgs/srvs (to be documented on the jackal_firmware ROS wiki page):
nmea_msgs/Sentence -> raw strings to and from globaltop module
sensor_msgs/IMU -> raw data from accelerometer and gyro
geometry_msgs/Vector3Stamped -> raw magnetometer data
std_srvs/Empty -> enable_motors, stop_motors services
std_msgs/Bool (?) -> wifi connected status
MCU parameters to be reviewed separately.
Placeholder for MCU firmware comments:
sensor_msgs/IMU isn't meant for truly raw data. Will need to determine where is best to scale to m/s^2, etc
I like going from least complex to most. So, PWM, then SPEED, then TORQUE
The reason it's as it is so that speed is the default. This ordering is "order of likelihood that it's what you want".

If we're always going to be sync'd between motors (which we should be), should we make that clear in this part by explicitly creating left_* and right_* members? IMO it'll be easier than arrays when using CLI tools to monitor
Based on my experience with Grizzly, it comes in handy having them be arrays rather than named members. It's a lot easier to assign names to the members than it is to produce an array after the fact.
Is "drivers_active" the enabled status? Otherwise known as the "/ESTOP"?
Yes, but I'd prefer to avoid "estop" terminology, since it isn't really one.
If we change the message period, are we going to autoadjust this in in firmware (as in, is it worth the trouble)? Maybe just say "1 Hz" for the average

It's easier to go by publish period than to say that it will always be a 1sec average. (ie, someone changes the period to 5Hz for some reason, then you need to track 5 separate averages-in-progress, ugh)
For which voltage level? If we're talking all voltages, what's the use you've got in mind? IMO a "lowest battery voltage" would be more usable for diagnosing brownouts.

VBATT—I believe all the currents are being measured upstream of the respective regulators, and it's VBATT feeding the PC and motor drivers. The use is to alert the user of overall system current spikes which may not be visible in the 1Hz averages. I agree that lowest-seen voltage would be useful as well.
An alternative way to do this would be to define a CurrentFeedback message with avg, peak, variance, whatever, and then use instances of those in this message. I'm not sold either way.
Where do we report MCU uptime?
Should be here. That's missing, thanks.
re: sensor_msgs/IMU
The intent is that the MCU will publish a data message suitable for consumption by
, using standard REP-103 units.
So, scaling will occur on the MCU, controlled by rosparams.
